Bottle. Reddish purple with pink head. Thick musty lambic aroma, some oak. Taste has more of the same with a hint of raspberry. Huge tart finish. Delish

In bottle, thanks Ben! Pours a ruby golden colour with a decent pink head. Aroma of lemon, raspberry, balsamic vinegar, caramel and eoak. Similar flavours with moderate carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. Nice and tart. Lovely!

75 cl bottle to oversized snifter (2009 vintage; shared with the Mrs. In celebration of my stellar fantasy football draft). Looks good; red raspberry with thin reddish-white tinted lacing. Smells good too; funky fruit. Tastes like it smells with a pleasant mouthfeel. YES!

Enjoyed with friends. 2004 Vintage enjoyed in a wine glass. Notes taken on iPhone

A - Hazy murky purple. Dark red. Cloudy. Nice pop of the cork. Borderline brown appearance.

S - Very light scent. Raspberry is there but weak. Very sort of grape jelly sent. Funk and tart.

T - Intense jammy raspberry taste. Lots of wood and some honey. Very acetic and funky. Some mustiness and mold. But its weak. Intensely tart.

M - 50% carbonation. Medium body. Huge gigantic sour tart finish

O - I really enjoyed this above all of the other bottles we enjoyed that night. Looking forward to having this again.

Bottle shared with drabmuh earlier this summer. Thanks Matt! Review from notes.

2007 vintage. Served side by side with Cantillon Rosé de Gambrinus.

This beer has a gorgeous appearance - a reddish-purple hue, with a pink foam head that sticks around longer than expected, and leaves no lacing, as is expected.

Wonderful aromas of raspberries, hay, barnyard funk. Classic Cantillon scents - simply wonderful. I could sniff this beer for several minutes without taking a drink. The aroma alone is worthy of praise and attention.

This beer is truly excellent. While definitely tart, I would not say that it is incredibly sour. Lou Pepe Framboise is extremely drinkable, and has a much milder acetic finish than the Rosé de Gambrinus. Very pleasant lingering tart raspberry aftertaste. A terrific offering from a fabulous brewery.

2009 decantered bottle to wine glass
Strong sour raspberry aroma with a bit of hay. Clear pinky red colour with a slightly pink tan head. The fruit taste is subtle and I get both raspberry and dark cherries with no sweetness and a lot puckery tartness.
2009, botella en Kitsch, VItoria. Quizá ha salido perjudicada en el agravio comparativo con la Framboos de 3Fontainen. También decir que cuesta 10 veces menos, por lo tanto qué decir,. dame una caja.

750 ml Bottle (2004 Vintage) - Red/copper with a pinky white head. Slightly musty and metallic aroma with raspberry also standing out. Sharp, tart and tangy taste with notes of metal, tart raspberries and must standing out. The sharpness is not overwhelming, but remains throughout the course of the bottle. Enjoyable, but I would like to try a younger version.
annata 2009 incredibilmente viva in bocca, note fruttate che fanno esplodere in bocca un gusto fresco e dissetante.

Bottle 750ml.
Pour hazy pink/red wth huge pink head. Some lacing. Aroma is of raspberries, acidity, sourness, sweet. Taste is of raspberries, sourness, acidity, sligth funkyness. Overall: Refreshing, nice funkyness. Nice balance. Very good beer.
Pours a beautiful ruby red with pink head. Aroma: raspberries and horse blanket. Taste: raspberries, horse blanket. Excellent balance. Pleasant acidity. Complex and refreshing. Great beer.

Bottle 750 ml. Red ruby with a beautiful small pink head and fair lacing. Aroma of raspberries, wood and horse blanket. Taste is of sour raspberries, wood with medium sourness and funkiness. Mouthfeel is acidic and carbonation is average. Overall, this is a nice complex fruit lambic with great balance and fair drinkability for the style.

2007 Bottle, tasted side-by-side with the Drie Fonteinen Framboos. Tasted from a Cantillon tumbler. Pours hazy red/purple, thick pink head, decent lacing, if a bit ropey. This is such a different beer from the Framboos, its crazy! Where Framboos was delicate and feminine, perfumed, this is big, and aggressively sour, and dirty and raunchy. This is hell on wheels lambic! The raspberries are here, but they play second fiddle to big, gorgeous, earthy, sweaty lambic notes. Flavours run to the sweaty as well, with raspberries, mineral, earth, straw, and horse. Big sourness, but controlled. Quite nice, but not Framboos.

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, dark red pour with white head, almost pink, pretty nice looking.  Aroma has notes of big raspberry, raspberry vine, some green grape, nice lactic, tart fruit, lemon, touch of vanilla funky notes.  Taste is big lactic acid, lemon, tart fruit, lemon, vanilla notes, scorching sour, finsihing with tons of raspberries and more tart fruit.  Wow, this is awesome.

Bottle @ Matts house. Maroon, pinkish purple appearance with light pink appearance. Well carbonated, somewhat acidic, fairly rich raspberry, big berry, light tannin aroma. Super rich raspberry, carbonated, soda-like, quite acidic, very sour, tart fruit flavor with a quite sour finish. Super sour. Nice stuff.

Aroma:hinbær Ud.:rød Skum:rød  E.smag:sød lidt sur lidt  Krop:medium For.:vandede Brus:livlig  
 28-5-11@ 20th Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation

75 cL bottle poured into a Cropton glass, 2008 bottle.  Effervescent before the head disappears completely.  Lovely cherry colour.  Dry and sour.  Pleasant raspberry aroma.  Its alright but could have been better.

Bottle of the 2005 at Monks, shared by Thomas and Denise.  Pours a hazed brown with ruby tinges about it, and a thin off white head.  Big fruit, raspberry puree, but theres definitely some age present.  Soft acid and funk.  Classic Cantillon acid and vinegar, funky and musky.  Lots of long lingering acid and fruit.  The fruit is still present, but fading a bit.  Lemon juice and long acid on the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2012 2007 vintage bottle shared at Klooster, Delft.  Hazy red/orange pour with a small pink head that disappears quickly.  Aroma is strong tart sour raspberry.   Flavour very tart, but the fresh raspberry seems to mellow the mouth puckering quality.  Soft carbonation and medium bodied.  A fine example of the style.

Poured into a tulip. Brewed in 2009 (label), bottled in 2011 (cork).

3.5 A: Fairly clear plum colored first pour. Three fingers of fizzy pink head that falls quickly and leaves no lacing.

4.5 S: Raspberry is huge in this. Tart, sweet, and powerful. Like any good Cantillon fruit, this is full of acid, but low on funk. Tons of lactic acid with a mild to moderate acetic component. Underneath there is a light musty basement type funk.

4.0 T: Moderately sour with a good tart pucker factor. Raspberry and tangy lactic acid galore. Surprisingly, theres a good bit of funk in there as well. Musty basement, rotting wood, and a mild cheesiness. Sharp, tart raspberry finish. 

3.0 M: The mouthfeel is kinda dull. Lighter medium body. The carbonation is on the lower end for the style, but good enough. The problem is that it isnt very spritzy. Creaminess is lacking as well. This sits rather dead on the tongue.

4.0 D: Tasty framboise. A bit hard to justify the price, but good for a special occasion, like a Pens playoff game.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-19-2012 01:35:27

A - pours red/orange amber with low white head that clings. S - very sour aromas, vinegar/eggs, notes of raspberry, apple, and funk. M - very sour up front, aggressive even, simple clean and strong palate. Lingering sour. T - sweet tarts, sour vinegar, and raspberries up front and throughout. Lightly alcohol warmed, sour end. O - great fruity gueze. 8-

Vintage 2009. Bottle @ home. Looking forward to the Lou Pepe. Light hazy deep red coloured beer with some medium carbonaiton and a large but diminishing pink head. Light refreshing fruity and raspberry hinted aroma. Medium to full palate. Finish is refreshing light tart and fruity raspberry hinted with a longer fruity and mouth-cleansing ending. This is top.

Bottle. Pink-purple pour with pink-white head. Raspberries, oak, slight funkiness. Tart, mouth puckering, dry finish, overall outstanding especially on the palate as the tartness and a vinegar note really sustain.

Bottle. 2007 edition. Poured a cloudy plum purple color with a creamy white head and bubbles. Aromas of sour raspberry, buttery oak, light malt, and some blood orange. Taste was very funky and filled with sour fruit and vanilla woody malts. Amzingly balanced and layered lambic. 3 years of age made it ultra soft as well. Great framboise.

reviewed 12-07-2011. vintage 2008 bottled in 2010. pours a deep pinkish ruby with a light fizzy pink head that quickly dissipates. deep fresh raspberries with some fresh oak mixed in. slight funkiness. very ripe and juicy. a bit toned down from the regular rose de gambrinus but still vibrant. a strong mix of fresh raspberry and fresh oak. very well blended and complex however these two main flavors seem to really balance each other. more sour than i would have expected up front however after a bit it feels toned down. very light and easy with a mild mix of carbonation through out. dryness from the oak. very good, better than the rose de gambrinus for sure. a solid framboise.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2014 Ok, one of my last final rates before I retire and turn professional with my current beer project. As Cantillon has been such a remarkable and shamefully ignored brand I feel I should include them in my final rates

On the eye this beer is extremely pleasant. Extremely red on the side but if you hold it up to the light there is a lovely sunbeam golden red colour which is really stunning. it is very hazy and dark but the colour is still gorgeous.

The aroma is raspberries; perfume, white wine grapes and very faint lemons. The taste is plenty of strawberries, a sweet and ripe texture, the acidic levels is quite sharp and dry, very tarty but not too aggressive. The palate is sticky and almost lemon-tart like but very drinkable and an interesting taste of maybe elderflower combined with the raspberries. Really complex and challenging to describe.

The sourness sticks to your mouth for quite some considerable time afterwords and this is no complaint. The finish is incredibly long; vinegary and woody. This beer is a bottle from 2008 and has evened out well. A classic lambic. Bought from Utobeer in Borough Market, London.

From notes.  First reviewed 9/26/2011.  2006 Vintage. Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tasting glass.

The cloudy color is instantly recognizable as the only color raspberries can be. A nice soft white froth gently recedes to a ring around the edge along with a few wisps of lace.

The raspberry in the aroma is quite sour. There are some light malt notes, and some good funk in there, but at this point it is mostly sour.

The raspberry flavor in this beer is just brilliant. With five or so years in the bottle, the flavor has become balanced between tart and funky. 

I suspect that over time the body has dried out and lightened up a bit as the beer continued to develop. At this stage the body is on the light side of medium, with medium strength fizzy carbonation. Somewhat acidic, but not overly so. 

I am a sucker for good raspberry sours, and this is probably my favorite one at this point. Simply fantastic, I would like to always have this in my fridge, and my future beer purchases will probably reflect that desire.
Bottle shared at the RBWG in Austin.  Reddish pour with an off-white head.  Aroma is sweet, fruity, vinegar, and cheap cigars.  Taste is raspberry, sour, very sweet, almost chocolate, and malty.
On tap at Pangea Two Brews during beer week. One of the best sours Ive had. Very little carbonation; mild fruitiness considering the color.

Vintage 2001- Bottle at RBWG..Nose is fruits,citrus,tartness, floral., Taste is grapefruit, blood orange , sourness and tart, A lot going on with the flavor, very nice balance of fruit and sourness...My be the best Lambic ive had.

Rated from file. 2007 vintage consumed May 2011.
Look: White-raspberry head, fiery blood-orange/ruby grapefruit color
Smell: Sweet, jammy raspberry underscored by a well-integrated funky note. Very inviting.
Taste: Significantly more sour than the regular framboise, but equally matched by a robust raspberry flavor. Smelled like it would be sweetish, but the flavor is definitely full-on sour. Finishes dry, tangy and tart, with a hint of the jam returning at the end to counter the sour flavor.
Mouthfeel: The carbonation seems somewhat subdued after several years of aging, but still enough to keep the beer from being too cloying.
Overall: Exceptionally well-integrated- a top-flight sour beer. Makes a believer out of me, a [now former] fruit hater.

Bottle from bleeng.Pours cherry red with a nose of pungent cherry water wrung from a horseblanket.  Flavor is wet cherry blanket on a horse in a musty barn.  Uber tingly and seductive on the tongue.  Does this brewer make a non-awesome beer???
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text:
0,75 l bottle as a gift.
Hazy reddish beer with some brown copper tone, small white froathy head. Fine aroma with vanilla, tarty sourish and earthy fruitiness. Tart character, grapefruit and lactic acid, berries and oak. Complex one!

2005 vintage.  Bottle shared at Brasserie 4:20 in Rome.  Alex is the man and has gone to great lengths to insure that his vintage bottles are cellared correctly.  This bottle was fantastic.  Clear garnet pour with an off white head.  The aroma was pure luscious raspberry.  The taste was absolutely dominated by tart raspberries.  To be honest, I expected the fruit to be almost gone and instead replaced by sour funk notes.  Nothing could be farther from the truth.  The were some acidic notes and even a hint of vinegar, but the funk and barnyard flavors I have come to expect were non-existent.  This bottle was crisp, clean, and refreshing.  Simply outstanding.......
750ml bottle. Vintage 2008. Deep red with huge pink, collapsing head. Sour raspberry aroma. Refreshing tart raspberry taste. Palatable carbonation. Still not my favourite style.

Bouteille de 750ml. Millésime 2008. Que dire de cette superbe lambic à la framboise. La robe est rose-rouge avec une mousse rose qui ne tient pas la route. Le nez est bien acide, les levures sauvages sont aussi présentes. Rien de détonne. Les framboises sont bien intégrées mais perceptible. La bouche est fort agréable. Elle est acide mais le corps bien constitué rend le tout agréable. Les framboises sont bien présentes en fin de bouche. Une des meilleures selon moi.

(Vintage 2008, 75 cl)  Une tête rose qui disparaît sur un liquide à la robe rouge et embrouillée.  Un nez très agréable de basse-cour, détable et de bois mouillé avec des framboises appétissantes, fraîches et acidulées.  Des saveurs de fermentation sauvage, une belle aigreur qui attaque les muqueuses avec des notes boisées et une juste touche de fruits rouges qui apportent un certain réconfort.  Une bouche au corps moyen avec une effervescence à la Cantillon et une texture huileuse.  Une finale qui a du mordant, un arrière-goût fruité et chargé de notes surettes.

2008 bottle. Pours a dark burgundy with a thick pink head. Nose is barnyard funk with lots of sour and raspberry. This is a young bottle with only a year and change so the taste is a bit more earth than pure sour funk however there is a good amount of funk with the raspberry. Drink soon if you want to taste more raspberry or wait for more sour.  Mouthfeel is crisp and sharp. Always quality from Cantillon. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 04-11-2011. Pours pretty dark red with a pink head. Smell is not spectacular, raspberries in the end. Taste is a perfect combination between the lambics and the raspberry although i miss a wow feeling here. I do miss a sourness, its good but not overwhelming.
A good fruit geuze after a hard day of cleaning out the garage. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
I was surprised by the round body. Lots of raspberries, stable, earth. Sourness was perfect. That thing is awesome.

75 cl bottle @ home, bottled 19.01.2010, BBE 12/2012
Tart and sourish aroma with raspberries, some earthy notes and hints of vinegar. Really sour and tart aroma with raspberries, earthy notes and vinegar. I love the big sourness here, but somehow it fits even better to the cherry aromas of Kriek. The berries come a bit too much through, especially on the dry finish. Adding the yeast gives some slightly unpleasant notes of sour cream  do not do it. Rather foamy palate. Probably the best raspberry beer Ive had.

Draught at Akkurat. Stockholm, 30th September 2011. 

Sweet sourish aroma of fresh raspberries. Its phenomenal! Its juicy and rich with a big zesty finish that definitely says Cantillon! The taste is very fruity and clean with a big raspberry punch. Its very sour, on the edge of being acidic. Very tart and with some barnyard notes.

Bottle from Nelson Wines. It pours deep ruby-red, with a massive light pink head. The nose is juicy raspberry, floral, cherry lipsol, strawberry and rose. The taste is juicy fresh raspberry, tart lemon, Granny Smith apple, wood, floral, strawberry and metal, with a refreshingly tart finish. Lively carbonation, medium body, med-high sourness, good balance and velvety mouth-feel. Great stuff.

Bottle. Dark reddish, hazy, small to average and fully diminishing pink head. Moderate, dryish and sour aroma, fruitiness- raspberries, vinous, some oak. Moderate, dryish and sourish flavor, fruitiness  raspberries. Finish is average, dry and sour, fruitiness - raspberries, light oak. Nice lambic, aroma/flavor in balance - not too sour.

(750ml 2008 Vintage ) The air fills with pungent Cantillon signatures..that uncompromisig sour nature that scares and excites....rustic raspberry ,blood , faint must  Looks like a purple potion in my Cantillion tulip .  Yes the customary  bone dry nature is a joyus lunacy that I love as a Lambic lover  , I just love tart dryness ,  the raspberry is a degenerate on the palate, not at all sweet or nice.  God bless Cantillon.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2011 21/10/2011 75cl bottle @ home - bottled: 29/9/2010 (2011-571)
Clear ruby red to almost fuchsia pink beer, small light pink head, pretty stable, non adhesive. Aroma: lots of raspberries, sour touch, little sweet (maybe its just the fruitiness messing with my brains), some bretta, bit dusty. MF: good carbon, medium body. Taste: very fruity, fresh raspberries, lemony, bit sour but not too much, bit of yoghurt. Aftertaste: pretty bitter notes for a geuze, more raspberries (sour ones), nice acidity.

0.75l bottle @ Grunerløkka Brygghus. Ah, this one pours a fantastic looking deep raspberry-hazy body with a nice big light pinkish head. The aroma is filled with fantastic raspberries, cherries, light lemonish and pretty much fantastic. Aggressive carbonation, medium-bodied and the mouthfeel is both fizzing and quite exciting. Flavors are dominated by light sourish raspberries with notes of lime and flowers. Ahhh, really refreshing and delicious! Ends dry with a light warming aftertaste. Really nice stuff!

Draught @ Akkurat on September 29 (incredibly happy to find something like this on tap in Sweden). Pours red with a small white head into a Cantillon glass. Smell has tons of freshly picked raspberries. Its quite sour and has a nice fullbodied complexity to it. Taste is very sour with boatloads of raspberries adding to the flavour. Its very fresh and drinkable and has a nice dry aftertaste with even more raspberries. Quite incredible!

On Tap @ Akkurat
Dark red appearence. Distinct aroma of raspberry, almost like must. Sweet taste, lite sour. Doesnt really feel like "beer", just a little in the aftertaste (my first lambic). Rather light feeling, smäll carbonation. 
Definitely something new to me with a pretty good taste.
Tap at Akkurat, stockholm. Pours red with no real head. Smells fruity and sour. Tastes creamy, fruity and very sour with a similar finish.

Tap @ Akkurat. Pours beautiful cloudy raspberry red with no head. Aroma is intense raspberry sweet sour stable. Flavor is fresh berry raspberry sour tart slightly lemon juice. Finishes nice sour and raspberry.

On tap @ Akkurat
Dipping nose over the glass and sensing a great aroma of raspberry jam and also some farmhouse and vinous notes. In the mouth the explosion of raspberry jam returns and its great. Later the typical Cantillon acidity comes and reminds you that this beer is a tough bastard. Lovely beer, went to have 2 big glasses of this wonderful beer.

Draught at Akkurat.
Pours red with a pink head.
Sweet and fruity taste of raspberries and a some bitterness of raspberry seed.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2017 New rate, May 2017: 75cl bottle. Vintage 2013, 3.5 years old. It pours a rich dark ruby purple color with a minimal bubbly pinkish head. Aroma is intensely sour and lactic with notes of vinegar, raspberries, taste cherries. Taste is also rich in sour vinegar notes, tart raspberries, vanilla and hint of twig. Light bodied with ok carbonation. Overall, very intense. 

Original rate, September 2011: 75cl bottle. Vintage 2005, 6 years old. Pours a cloudy ruby /brownish colour with a little off-white head. Aroma is stunning: tons of raspberries and horseblanket. Lightly sweet, quite acidic flavor, becomes moderately sour. Taste is really complex and fruity, but not sweet at all. Really sour, but still balanced thanks to the fruity presence. Acidic, pretty dry finish. Medium body, lively carbonation. World class, awsome. Score 8/3/9/3/19=4.2

This beer was absolutely wonderful, it was one of those experiences which actually had me taken aback. I drank this at a bar (Beerbistro, Toronto) and cannot describe in full detail. But it poured a dark ruby red with a thin white head. The smell was strong and fruity with a light acidity. The taste was wonderful, an exceptionally smooth palate, and a long complex aftertaste with fruit and funky sour flavours developing long after the beer had been swallowed. Slightly prickly on the tongue like a proper lambic should be. This was not brutally sour like their gueuze, but a restrained and well balanced sourness that left you refreshed and craving more. Wonderful wonderful wonderful.
Bottiglia comprata su ilbeershop.it; dolcezza e morbidezza esagerate, acido moderatissimo, una bevanda fantastica, di uneleganza superba.

750 ml bottle
A: berry, funk, earthy
T: tart, berry , hay/earthy
Not as complex as I would have liked, but still a solid beer.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2014 750mL bottle, pours a pinkish ruby red with a big pink head. Aroma of sour raspberries, funk and high acidity. Flavour is very tart and funky with extremely soured raspberries, tons of funk, and high acidity. Carbonation is high, with a lingering fruity sour finish. A classic framboise.

750mL bottle, split with mcberko, pours a pinkish ruby red with a big pink head. Aroma of sour raspberries, funk and high acidity. Flavour is very sour, with extremely soured raspberries, tons of funk, and high acidity. Carbonation is high, with a lingering fruity sour finish. Very good.

2008 version

Bright red/purple colour. Smells yeasty, wood. Tastes acidic sour and fruity. Long aftertaste, quite dry.

750ml bottle 
Appearance: Clear darkish red with a medium pink head and some lacing 
Aroma: Tart fruit and wet blanket 
Taste: Sour fruit, raspberry with a super dry finish 
Great, very enjoyable

750ml bottle. Pours a wonderful red hue with a tall thick pink head. The aroma is rich overripe fruits, some tannins and tart funkiness. The flavor is very nice; a massive very natural burst of fresh raspberries combined with a tart dry and very funky flavor. Oak and light dustiness. Very drinkable and accessible. Nice. Not overly complex but well made.

Bottle I shared at the August Houston RB Tasting.  2006 vintage.  Pours a clear red with a white head that was tinted light pink.  Nose is of funky cheese, sweaty socks and leather.  Taste is of tart raspberries that are not crisp anymore, but you are aware of them, and funk.  Mouthfeel is sour and musky.  This is what all sours should aspire to develop into.  This was freakin incredible!  Wish I had a case of these.

Tasted on 8/28/11 from a 750mL corked and capped bottle purchased at Discount Liquor, the label says 2005, but the cork says 2007.  Pours cloudy deep, dark red, with a thick white head that slowly recedes to a thin collar of lace.  The nose is amazingly sour and funky, with natural, tart raspberry, vinegar, and some oak treatment, but the overwhelming aroma is raspberry vinaigrette.  The flavor is pretty much the same, with super acidic sour lemon, some barrel treatment, but again, dominated by raspberry vinaigrette.  The body is light, and very tannic, with very lively carbonation, and a super long, acidic, raspberry vinaigrette finish.  This beer is an amazing experience, but it is very hard to rate due to the fact that it is quite hard to drink.

Bottle. Fing semi old bottle. Cork 04 date. Pours a rich red color with a light pink head. The smell is a pungent, musty, dusty raspberry. The smell is either really good cheese or really bad meat. Tanic and basement like. The taste is very funky and intense. Acidic, lemon, funk, and fruit. Really glad I got to taste this. The sourness sticks around for a while after your finish your drink.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2014 2006 bottle thanks to maltomeal at August tasting. Pours a cloudy red pink with frothy pink head. The aroma is rasberry, sour fruit, and tart. Thin mouthfeel with tart rasberry and nice lingering sour finish. Easy to drink an very clean. Really enjoyed this one.

2004 bottle thanks to Rick. Pours a hazy copper ruby with small off whie head that lasts leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is strong raspberry, oak, funk. Thick mouthfeel with nice tartness, lots of oak tannin, raspberry still very strong, nice funk. Very impressive.

2006 bottle thanks to maltomeal at the August 2011 tasting. Pours fluffy dark red, huge raspberry nose. Taste is full of fruit with a nice tart and sour base. Effervescent. Goes down way too fast as this is delicious.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: 2007... Ruby/Mahogany, fizzy fading head, no lacing... tart, barnyard, lightly sour, funky aroma, with big notes of raspberry... lively, wow wow wow, really really sour, thats awesome... sour raspberry dominates, some funk, some barnyard, lively, lightly citrusy, this is amazing... Tart, incredibly sour, so much flavor, funk, rasp, medium bodied, easy drinking... wow...

2007 vintage...pours a rosy opaque red/pink color with a thick pink head.  Aroma has significant funk...raspberry is made subtle by the funk.  Flavor is extremely sour!  Again...raspberry is almost hidden until the finish which lingers of funky raspberry.  Wow!  *pucker*

750ml 2008, bottled September 14, 2010. Hazy pale red with minimal rose head. Lots of farmhouse funk, raspberries, wood, not overly tart, very mellow. Well carbonated, tart, sour, somewhat thin, very dry, raspberry finish - but dies quickly. Good but not great.

Bottle, shared poolside in the 33 degree Medicine Hat sunshine. Pours a bright ruby with lively pink bubbly head. Aroma is tart raspberries and sour funk. Flavors of not-fully-ripened raspberries, dusty dry wood, and yoghurt. Mouthfeel is light, finish is dry and sour, but in a balanced way that lends to this beers endless drinkability.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Great opaque red purple body. Earthy aroma with abundant fruit flavours. Definitely a beer with character, the Lou Pepe has a powerful mouthfeel with the malt and raspberry flavours blending nicely. Especially the aftertaste has an uncommon kick, tart- and bitterness for the style.

Bottle:
Lively light pink head that disappears quick and leaves nothing on top of a nice deep pink rose red colored beer.
Smell dust, raspberry, yeast, wood, some (barnyard) bacteria and a hint of something light sour.
Taste has a medium sour (for Cantillon) taste mixed with red fruit, raspberry, yeast, dust, some hints of soap.
Dusty raspberry sour aftertaste.
Low carbo, full tingly mouthfeel, full body and alight watery texture.
Very well balanced brew.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Bottle said Cantillon Lou Pepe Framboise 2008. Clear red color, almost no head. Smell dust, sweat, barnyard and zalf (no idea what that is in English). Taste pretty good, actually like it a lot. How can it taste so good and smell so f*** bad!? Very good carbonation, medium body. Overall a good beer but I really cant stand the smell. Too bad.

750mL corked bottle.  Poured reddish-pink into glass with light pink head falling to a thin ring.  Strong smell of raspberries.  Initial taste of sweet raspberries, followed by the dry tartness of a lambic.  Good carbonation and medium body lends well to the palate of this brew.

framboise tasting @ kulminator ( NOTE: i was not in the tasting i only got a glass of it  ) 
head: none 
colour: deep watermelon red 
smell: sour, raspberry, almunds, gueuze/lambic 
taste: gueuze/lambic, raspberry/red fruits, tiny bit of sweetness, malts, soury bone dry tarty end , very good !!!!

Pääsin aikoinaan jo Lou Pepe Kriekiä maistamaan. Nyt on Framboisen vuoro. Se on kauniin kirsikan punainen olut, mutta kaunis vaaleanpunainen vaahto on erittäin nopeasti katoava. Tämä on maanläheinen ja hapan olut, joka ei näin sunnuntainakaan jätä kylmäksi.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2011 Appearance:  One of the few beers where looks really count.  Transparent, intense and vivid red raspberry and red rose.

Aroma:  Dry, tart red raspberry & some tart cherry. Floral and especially medicinal aromas.

Taste:  Tart, dry red raspberry, bitter medicinal/quinine flavors, yeast, and straw.  Finishes with a resurgence of tart dry red raspberry, medicinal and and rose hip tea flavors.  

Comment:  2008 Vintage.  Complex, but not an easy drinker.  This must be brilliant with the right food and certainly challenges the palate.  The low alcohol and acidity make it a relatively refreshing choice for summer, though I cant see a wine getting away with this much tartness.  Still, not as sour as the Rose de Gambrinus and without the oxidized notes that I experienced with that lambic..

Day 2:  

Aroma:  Red raspberry descends into a dry desert underworld of dusty straw, dried mold and a dash of rodent pee before triumphantly rising past metallic and medicinal aromas to finish with red berries and flowers.  Thats one crazy ride.

Flavor:  Medicinal and metallic notes that I overlooked yesterday, tart red raspberry merges with white grapefruit plus bitter grapefruit rind and these carryover into the finish which also shows some yeast and straw.

Good intensity from the mid-palate through a long finish.  Also, very fine carbonation.  Although this is an acquired taste, I could see giving this a 4.5 or 4.6 because it is well-made and complex.
Bottle @ Kaisla, Helsinki. Originally rated on 10.7.2010.  Great, well balanced and fruity lambic.
03 @dstructos Daks Back-750ml bottlepours a white ring for a head and hazy orange color.  Aroma is old socks, fruit, light/medium malt.  Taste is tart fruit, acidic, light/medium malt.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2013 75 cl. A light fruity smell, then it gets sour. The beer has a huge pink fizzy head with a short duration, the body is also pink. The taste is fruity, quite sour, a long finish which is a little bit sharp. The body is light, very dry and sour with a lively carbonation. A very good beer!

03 bottle shared at Dstructo/Daknole tasting. Quite a treat we have here. Super fruity tart aroma. Flavor was sour, tart, fruity and acidic. Dont know how else to describe this one, but  it was simply amazing.

2004 bottle generously shared at the RBSG grand tasting. Pours a hazy burnt orange. Incredible aroma, and I mean incredible! Juicy, fresh watermelon and raspberry are prominent and back by the perfect pinch of vinegar. I sniffed this over and over. Wonderfully tart flavor rich of raspberry, balsamic, and watermelon. There is a perfect balance of acidity and tartness. Its always intense but never throat-gagging. Absolute world class! I couldnt stop smelling it, and though it was a joy to taste, the hardest thing about tasting it was having less to smell.
Vintage 2008. Cloudy red with a pink head. Aroma is sweet, lots of raspberry and moderate sour. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and acidic finish. Watery. 110611

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2015 2001 bottle drank in Jan 2015. Dry raspberry nose, yogurt, barnyard, old books, lemon, spearmint. Wonderful nose. Beautifully clear orange-red, shining, with lace. Dry, funky, extremely sour flavor, leather and barnyard. Yogurt. Lovely flavors coming out. A touch of vinegar. Quite amazing after the initial shock of sourness. Teeth-strippingly dry. Only fault is probably that it is just too sour. This has aged so nicely. 

2008 Bottle from Ohtsuki san, drank in 2011 = 9/5/8/4/16. Amazing bright red, crimson, high, rocky, cyclamen head. Huge raspberry aroma, yogurt, vanilla, citrus, just a bit of funk. Sour and bitter fruit flavor, funky, a bit of harshness, metallic, crystal, quite sour, lemony. Not as wonderful as the last LP Kreik we had, somewhat too harsh at first, though the second glass got much better and richer.
Orange pour with light to no head or lace. Aroma is a hay and sour malt. Very sour almost acidic with a very nice tartness. A thin beer but with a pH like this it would have to be. nice.

2001 Milder Himbeergeruch, sehr sauer. Saurer, aber noch zurückhaltender Antrunk mit extrem milder Fruchtigkeit. Das Bier wird nun stark sauer, die Fruchtigkeit wird nur minimal stärker, festigt sich dafür aber im Hintergrund. Die natürliche Säure ist außerordentlich füllend und ist absolut speziell, meinen Geschmack trifft es. Aromatischer saurer Abgang mit angenehmen Fruchtnoten, citrus. Vielen Dank an den Doppelbock für das Bier! /13/10/12/12/12

2008 this time. Pours a deep, dark, blood red. Small pink head that fades pretty quickly. Very fruity aroma. A slight musty and funky odor. Like grandmas basement. Cork, raspberry seeds, grass, eraser, and fresh raspberries. Raspberry taste. A little perfumeness to it. Quite tart, but not bad at all. A slight sweetness mixed with a sour funkiness. Very carbonated, the head gets refreshed after putting down the glass upon finishing each drink. A tart aftertaste. Excellent.
This is perhaps my favorite LP so far.
Bottle. Pours pinkish red. Pink head. Nose/taste of tart raspberry, wild yeast, balsamic vinegar, wood and tannins. Good solid body.

Bottle 2007. Poured hazy purple color with an average fizzy purple head that lasted with good lacing. Good tart raspberry & yeast aroma. Medium body with tingly texture and flat carbonation. Moderate raspberry tar fruit flavor with a solid tart fruit and small alcohol bite finish of moderate to long duration. Very good beer.

Brassin 2008. Bouteille verte de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, partagée avec MartinT et Fred82. Arôme: Odeur de framboises et de vinaigre de framboises. Apparence: La couleur est rouge. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Léger goût de vinaigre de framboises avec une très légère pointe dépices. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture vineuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de framboises en arrière goût. (Rating #3602)

I feel bad. Lots of people love this stuff and have problems finding it. I just force myself to drink this because it happens to be in a book. I will never like any Guezes/Lambics. Sorry guys.

Appearance: Bottled 19/1-10, cap & cork. Dark cherry red. Some pink head.
Aroma: Lots of raspberry, some sourness and wet wood.
Taste: Wow, sour and quite a bit of raspberry. Not my thing.
Info: 750ml bottle, 7/3-2011, 36/100

2007 vintage...very awesome. Beer is PINK and hazy and forms a nice pink head with moderate to high carbonation. The head falls away leaving no lacing on the glass (its not expected to). Looks great.

Aroma is sour and tart with some acetic notes and strong raspberry character. One of the best smelling beers Ive ever had. Classic Cantillon smell.

Beer is very tart and not as acetic as I thought it was going to be, this is probably a good thing but the acetic character would likely grow over time slightly. There is nice raspberry flavors and good fruit tartness at the back. Some lactic notes and a slightly tannic quality overall as well. Nice carbonation in the mouth and highly drinkable. This could be one of my favorite Cantillons so far.

Serving type: bottle

2005 vintage from the bottle into a champagne glass.

This lambic pours a medium pink/violet with about 2 inches of light pink head. The retention is poor as it falls within a minute. The lacing is light and watery. 

The aroma is wonderful. There is the great funky horse blanket similar to what you get with the Saint Lamvinus, but this is far superior to the SL because it rewards you with great notes of sweet raspberries to balance out the tart.

The taste is also equally balanced rewarding the drinker with tartness and just enough sweetnes that a true lambic follower is looking for to enhance the drinkability. The first sip is lightly sweet with a raspberries and finishes with lots of sourness. 

The mouthfeel is heavy and full and coats your mouth and makes you pucker.

Because this is so balanced its exceedingly drinkable for something so tart.

Overall, this is a great beer. I would seek this out and cellar it for up 20 years as recommended on the bottle.

Bottle. Pours a brilliant sparkling pinkish amber with a rocky brilliant white head. Beautiful looking beer. Aromas are amazing. Grass, hay and some wood support a brilliat sweet baslamic vinegar sourness. Deep musty funkiness completes the brilliant nosw. Great stuff. Flavours are pretty much as expected. Very very sublte sweetness initially before the deep sourness comes through. Slightly dry chalky finish. Medium mouthfeel completes another brilliant cantillon beer.

2007 vintage

A-pours a bright ruby red color with an extremely light pink colored bubbly head.

S-the nose has a hint of earthy mushroom funk to it, light sweeter oak presence, the fruits are rather bright and the raspberry is seedy and fresh, it has a hint of tartness.

T-the taste is slightly muted in comparison to the nose.  the acidity picks up in the finish and detracts from the brightness of the fresh raspberries.  the funk is up front and well integrated with a note of oak and earthy flavors.  the rapberry in back starts sweet but the acidity really presents a problem for it to push through.

M-medium bodied beer with a slightly syrupy feel to it and high carbonation with a very dry finish.

D-put up against many other lambics and sour raspberry ales, the acidity of some of these, including this one, take away from the juicy fruit flavors you get in the nose.  the integration is done very well but this would probably be best drank fresh.

2004 Vintage drank 4/10

A-pours a completely hazed orangish amber color with an egg white head the is creamy and fluffy in appearance

S-the nose is tart and sour up front with notes of acidity, a touch of lactose and funk. Tons of tart raspberries in the back.

T-this is acidic and tart, sour raspberries take over with notes of earthy musk underneath. Hints of vinegar and a light bitterness, tons of tartness at the finish.

M-medium to full body that is smooth on the palate with some light bitterness. Nice strong carbonation presence giving a good crisp finish.

D-this is tasty and tart, nice flavors and lots of raspberries. Great Brew

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  The nose is a mix of bright raspberries and a good bit of funk.  I swear there is some garlic in there too.  It reminds me of my old Polish neighbor.  A bit of sweat, onion, kielbasa, and garlic.  Holy sheep shit this stuff is tart!  Good raspberry and oak prescience but a bit acetic.  This brew just keeps hammering too.  Pours a deep pink, almost red color with a foamy pink head.  Light in body with high carbonation and a tart, clean finish.  Awesome but a bit over the top for me.

thought id reviewed this already but.. . Pours a deep cherry purple, light foam, some light lacing .. . hay, wood, and berry in the nose .. . balsamic raspberry vinegar, wood, cherry, dark fruits, and vinegar.. . a great framboise lambic, another awesome cantillon product, and Danger is my middle name ..
Vintage 2004 popped post pre-sex.  HAzy pink pour with a fizzy white head.  Aroma is dusty raspberry, lacto, and horse blanket.  Very sour, very fruity, very nice

2005 Vintage Served on tap at Ebeneezers 8/2/2008

Poured into a wine glass deep, clear red grape color with almost no head. Aroma is sour funk and lots of raspberrys. Taste is raspberry and funk. Quite acidic, a most puckering experience. Crisp carbonation. I really liked this one, but its not for the faint of heart as the sourness of this one was intense.
dark red coloured body with pink white head a sweet fruity sour aroma a fruity (framboize) soury sweet taste with a sour bitter finish
Hazy red coloured beer with a small pinkish head and only few carbonation visible. Few fruity aroma. Full sour palate. Finish is sour fruity with a nice taste of berries. Nice one. (@WE - 15/01/11)

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2011 750mL 2004 ed thanks to ygtbsm94. Pours a clear, very light pink with a scant, white head. Looking like an unblended and certainly not a rich looking as LP Kriek. Aroma of raspberry preserves, bright grapefruit, true Cantillon subtle funk, fresh berry yogurt. Taste is very sour, bitter citrus for balance, lemon yogurt, woody tannins, lots of geuze character more than just raspberry. The base lambic here is center stage. Mouth watering all the way. Lactic sour palate devastation. Super wet mouthfeel. 1/11/2011 8/4/8/5/16=4.1750mL 2001 ed thanks again to ygtbsm94. Pours a fire amber red with an excellent pink head that is extremely healthy for a sour albeit a little fizzy. Aroma is unreal: so much fresh raspberry, raspberry preserves, and insanely sharp funk. Taste is sharp, ultimate level of lactic acidity, seedy raspberries, rhubarb, sorrel, and starchy earth. Palate is all consuming, zippy, dry, insanely powerful but quick on your body. What a complete devastation of the framboise category.  I cannot believe it but Puzzl and others are right- there is some serious aging potential for krieks and framboise. This has become sharper and more fruity heavy with 10 years on it rather than more mellow. 2/12/2011 9/4/8/5/16=4.2

Loved This!! Drank one bottled in 2007. Poured a delicate sparkling pink (less intense color than the Kriek) Aroma of berry, herbs, and lemongrass. Great lemony tartness in the beginning .Yeast and raspberry throughout, but with plenty o sour you know you want in a lambic. Light body with fizzy/lively carbonation that really allowed the berry flavor to shine. Quite astringent with a crisp finish.

07 bottle.  Translucent cherry red in the glass with a frothy head and heavy carbonation.  Aroma is bone dry raspberry, underlying funk, lemon peel, and slight tart.   Incredibly focused and tight aroma.  Holy crap - taste is sharp and dry tart raspberry up front, a relatively clean mid-palate, and the most ridiculously tight series of tart/sour notes through the finish that I have ever experienced.  This beer is f-cking amazing.
A beautiful 2004 bottle.  Pour is hazy brownish color with almost no head.  Aroma is tart and funky with notes of fruit, hay, and malt.  Flavor is tart and lightly sweet.  Very clean and delicious.

750 mL bottle, 2007, at the Thirsty Monk. Pours dark burgundy with a quick beige head. The aroma is quaint raspberry, dry white cheese (parmesan perhaps?), oak, chardonnay, and a mild mustiness. The flavor is dry raspberry and light cheese with a bunch of barnyard-like must (much more than in the aroma) and some distant grain. The finish is a lovely dry acidity, but leaves a fruity aftertaste. Delicious.

A: Poured a very nice reddish pink with a beautiful pink-hued head that lasted throughout the glass.

S: Lots of raspberries in this vintage with a nice bit of sweetness from the raspberries paired with a bit of tartness and quite a bit of lactic acid, seemingly much more so than in the LP Kriek. 

T: Quite tart with a bit of sweetness. Not much acetic acid, not getting any vinegar taste like with Saint Lamnivus. Much more on the lactic side of things. Not much funk, but overall very delicious.

M: Very nice. Ive gotten quite used to all types of sour, but this one actually stung my tongue quite a bit. Lots of carbonation.

D: Extremely drinkable. Low abv, very complex, and an all-around nice sipper.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-03-2010

härligt syrlig och med ljuvliga toner av körsbär utan att bli söt och sliskig som vissa andra Framboise jag har provat tidigare. Cantillon har hittat en perfekt balans mellan frukten och syrligheten, och det är bara att luta sig tillbaka och njuta.
75cl bottle, 2007. Red colour with a small pink head. Lots of raspberries and some vinegar in the aroma. Raspberry flavour with some spices. Very sour finish. Excellent lambic.

2005 bottle. Consumed 2010. Phone rate while sharing  with ky.  Pours a clear pinkish red hue with a medium tigjht frothy offwhite head.  Initial aroma is a burst of bright lactic sourness yet creamy raspberries.  Awesome fruit character.  Layered, raspberry cream pie.  So good.  Flavor is moderate to heavy lactic sourness with the perfect raspberry seed fruit with some light creamy basement funk undertones.  Ultra dry.  For my tastes, perfect lactic acid fruit balance.  Awesome beer.

Poured clear red with active pink bubbles that formed a small head that quickly gave way.  The aroma was mild funk, tart raspberry and some faint must and wood.  The flavor was acidic raspberry with some light funk and wood giving it an amazing personality.  Thin bodied, very dry and insanely drinkable.  Damn near epic.

(750ml bottle 2007 vintage thanks to mora2000) Rating #2200 - opaque red pour with pink bubbles that last throughout and excellent lacing. Nose of wet barrel, raspberry puree, lacto, mild barnyard funk, smells so delicious. Taste is very very tart raspberries, mildly sweet, wet barrel, mouth watering that makes you want to drink more, lasting tart lactic finish with crisp carbonation that is absolutely perfect. A fantastic fruit lambic.

750mL bottle, vintage 2007 bottled 09/09.  Pours clear bright red with a frothy light pink head that settles to a ring.  Complex aroma, raspberries and acid as expected but with some nice characters of smoke, possibly bacon, pine, a little mint and some esters, bubblegum maybe?  High tartness, the fruit is present, slightly savoury and a very slight late bitterness.  Light body, slightly tingly with a medium tart finish.

2006 vintage. Amber with a reddish tinge. Off-white head is barely pink and fades to a rim. Aroma has dull raspberries (nothing plump, luscious or hairy about them), vinegar and plenty of the barn. Rather less raspberry in the taste and theyre not there separately at all. Theres fruity wheat and deep sourness with a fabulous creamy/ slippery texture. a little like kefir. Slightly less complex (and less confronting) than the Kriek but the flavours are very well integrated.

2007 vintage. I had been saving this bottle and opened it in celebration of trying my 2000th beer.

The beer pours a reddish-purple color with a pink head. A great looking beer. The aroma is great. I get a lot of raspberries, but hidden in the background is the Cantillon funk that I love so much. The flavor is even better than the aroma. I get tart raspberries, oak and some of the Cantillon funk. The beer is so dry that it makes your mouth water as soon as you drink it. The salivary glands are working in overdrive. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. 

Not only one of the best sours I have ever tried, this is one of the best beers I have had period. It more than lived up to the hype. Well worth the $29 I paid for the bottle and I would buy another bottle again in a heartbeat.

Bottle shared by Joe, thanks! Poured a cloudy amber orange with a light pink head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma had earthy funk with lots of sour raspberries and some acid. Flavor was very tart from the raspberries and melded well with the earthy funk. I really love Cantillon!

Sampled at Cantillon. Pours dark red with a rose small head. Aroma reminded me of picking some raspberries from together with my grandmother, very fresh and inviting as well. Taste is fresh, sour but in no way aggressive or overpowering due to some fruity sweetness.

(2007 version, 750 ml bottle @ Oluthuone Kaisla, Helsinki. Rated @ 10.7.2010.)
Pours a deep red colour with a beautiful pink head which doesnt last. Lots of aged raspberries and cherries on the nose. The aroma is sweet fruitiness which turns into dryness dominated by the cherries. The palate is medium bodied with lively carbonation. Extremely sour and dry finish. Awesome brew once again from Cantillon.

2006 Bottle at Sergios World Beers.  Aroma is tart and raspberrys everywhere. Taste is wheaty, silky, and straw-like. Pours a vibrant, clouded raspberry red.  Raging citric acid, french raspberry jam, and searing lactic acid.  Complex and gets better as it warms.
75cl bottle at home vintage 2000. See my rate of the Lou pepe kriek. I bought a case, hated it then after trying a few training wheel lambics loved it. An epic framboise.
02 bottle thanks to Kramer. Lactic acids, sweet carmael malts. Body is almost creamy and smooth. Fruity, berries, color is fading red. Carbonation is still stinging on the tongue. Tasty sour. yumm

Bottled in 02. Thanks, mikey711.

Who needs fresh fruit when you have Lou Pepe Framboise? The raspberry character is so marked you can feel the drupelets on your tongue. Something in the acid has kept them in stasis.

Its sour enough to remind you of a vinaigrette. A funky, oaky vinaigrette. How many vitamins are still present in this liquid? Is it feasible to make this my primary source of dietary fiber? These are the questions I ask myself.

Upending the bottle, I expect to see whole raspberries in suspension. Nope, just yeast porridge. I drink it anyway.
user_location: The Court of the Crimson King, California, USA

text: Bottled 75cl. Pink head. Mediocre head retention. Complex and extremely delicious.

2004 vintage - Pours murky, rosy amber with very little head. The nose is...wow...really pungent. Smells like someone mixed rotting raspberries with moldy cheese, farts, dirt, animal poop, and sweaty socks. I get that this is an acquired smell, and it got better the more I smelled it, but dear God--that is some funky nastiness. The taste is a total 180. Tons of tart raspberries right as it enters your mouth, then smooths out and transitions into a bone dry finish. Raspberry, lemon, and orange rind on the finish, which also tastes a little salty. Smooth and well-carbonated, this beer is weird as hell but one that I had to have in my quest to appreciate true lambic.

Burgundy with a thin pinkish white head. The aroma is moderately strong and has characteristics of sour raspberries, vinegar, apples, and hard cider. The taste is extremely sour - pretty much all I can get from it is the sour raspberries. Right at the end there is a slight vinegar flavor that transitions into an aftertaste.

Courtesy of Pailhead. Hazy reddish, whispy head, film. Huge funky/musty raspberry character in aroma, faint oak/wood. Flavor has quick sour/tart twinge up front, overripe raspberry through the middle, oak, light vaniilla in the finish. Long lingering raspberry. Finishes very dry, well attenuated.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2013 2007 vintage opened July 2010 and served alongside a rich homemade chocolate mousse.
A: Medium red body. Slight pinkish hues. Thin, fizzy pink head quickly crashes into a broken collar around the edges. No lacing.
S: Bright raspberries. Nice sweetness with an underlying tartness and sourness that complements it well. Slightly earthy with decent funk.
T: Like the nose, this is all about the raspberries. Not overwhelmingly sweet, but nice and juicy. The sourness and tartness is present but is not puckering... my guests that had never had a true framboise were not bowled over with so much sourness that they couldnt enjoy it! Its got that underlying funk that most cantillon lambics have.
M: Effervescent with assertive carbonation. Medium bodied. Well balanced between sweet and sour/tart. 
O: Top notch. The Lou Pepe fruit lambics never fail me.

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. I think it needs a few years to let the sweetness settle and even up with the nice funk that resides in the background.

Bottle from Utobeer market stall. Dark orange pour with a salmon pink head, soon dissipates. Sour, funky nose with plenty of ripe raspberries, cheese and herbs. Crisp flavours of lemon rind, fresh raspberries, fresh herbs. Excellent sweet/sour balance. Fruit laden finish with a good sour edge. Cracking stuff.
750ml bottle 2007 vintage.  Lightly hazed reddish pink with a nice creamy off pink head. Very tart berry fruits with good acidity and faint vinous qualities.

2005 bottle sample at the HSC Sour tasting on 6/19/10. Clear pink/red pour with a thin off-white head. Funky nose with vinous fruit and vinegar notes. Raspberry flavor with pepper, lemon juice and a sour vinegary finish. No subtlety here, but nicely done for a framboise.

Bottle at Belgian Cafe. 25.4 oz. (2005 Vintage). Split with James and shared with Marlina. Pours a turbid, electric ruby with a thin, bubbly white head which quickly recedes and leaves a slight white lace across the surface. Aroma of raspberries, plums, dates, tart dark cherries, oak, sour white grapes, and Belgian candied sugar. Amazingly mild body, with a distinctly sour, yet uncommonly smooth palate. The five years of age on this guy definitely mellowed it out substantially, and allowed much more complex flavors to surface and mingle. Excellent lambic, and a truly unique, special drinking experience.
0.75l - Ruby red pour, pink head, nice carbonation.  Sour yeast nose.  Musty sourness without overpowering the palate.  A good example of the style.  Price does not equal value here.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2010 Bottle split with pat at Belgian. Bottle reads 2005 Vintage. Pours a hazy red body with nice white lacing. Aroma is extremely tart. Mouthfeel is complex and sour.. and notes of sour cherries, grape, wine, and superb tartness..

Sample at the HSC Sour Beer Tasting on 06/19/2010: 2005 vintage courtesy of JaBier. The beer is a clear reddish-amber color with a medium fizzy pinkish-white head that burns away steadily. Thin rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of raspberry yogurt, malt and oak. Medium body with a moderately tart raspberry character along with earthy malt, slightly metallic hops and oak. The finish is fruity with a lingering sour raspberry aftertaste. Very good Lambic all around.

2004 Vintage.  750 ml bottle opened to celebrate my wifes 50th birthday. Pours a hazy raspberry pink/red with no head except for a short string of bubbles that hug the wall of the glass and quickly disappear.  Very pleasant aroma that is noticeably tart, raspberries, a bit of mild funk as well.  The flavor is again tart with a bit of mild funk, raspberries, and some balsamic vinegar.  Drank more like a glass of wine than a beer, particularly with the lack of carbonation.  Very enjoyable.

(Old BA rate - bottle)
Ruby reddish color; poured with a very thin white head. Fruity tartness; fresh raspberries; hint of cherry; bit of vinegar; then again with the raspberry finishing the aroma. Beautifully tart; fresh raspberries and wild strawberry flavors; light on the vinegar but definitely present; mild funkiness as well. Really nice. Thinner; effervescent carbonation. Really awesome

Bottle. Pours red with a pink head. Lots of forest raspberries in aroma. Actually quite sweet, with an earthy note aswell as some sourness. The taste is not as sour nor as complex as a lot of the other Cantillon beers. Sweet of raspberry and some earthiness. This is a great beer to combine with different desserts.
A great lambic with a slight sour aftertaste.  Not too over powering or sweet with raspberry.  A refreshing taste.  Must have.

2006 bottle from State Line. Epic, lustrous pink pour, with enough sediment and cloudiness to promise complexity and aged funk but still with that suprisingly vivid hue. The nose is expansive, a jolt of fresh berry giving way to funk, cheese, and hay. Delightfully dense mouthfeel, its always a pleasure to linger over Cantillons. As far the taste, its lively and fresh but framed overall by the super funk, the tartest of tart. Superb craft all the way.

750 ml bottle; 2003 vintage; thanks tom for sharing; light, hazy red with thin white head; tart, fizzy cherries; nice level of fruity sweetness and a touch of poopy funk in the nose; drinks dry with stale cherries, some sweetness and fizzy funk; thin, dry, tart and fruity; delicious; yea, I dumped a big glass :)

Original Rating 9/29/09 (Score - 4.0): Draft @ Brouwers Sour fest; lovely dark red with trace tan head; tart cranberries with lovely texture; killer fruity nose with a rich sweetness that melds out the sourness; this was quite tasty and my fav Cantillon of the day

Murky dark red color with minimal head and some lacing. Man does this get cheesy with age. So funky but delicious. Lots of fruit on the aroma, slightly sour and some barnyard. Flavor is sweet/ tart, some candy, acidic, citrus, tart raspberries and funk. Some cheesy goodness and a nice creamy mouthfeel. Ages really well IMO.

Bottle, tfs Vaiz! Brownish cassis pour, thin head.
Aroma is a lovely fresh sourness, no fan of sours but this is awesome.
Intense brett sourness with sweet red fruits, nice balance.
Lingers on for ever.

Bottle at tasting. Pours a clear purple to pink color with a thin white head. Aroma of raspberries, brett and more fruits. Flavor is very sour, blueberries, raspberries, blackcurrant, nice and refreshing. Quite lively carbonation and a bubbly texture.

2004 vintage. Thanks Hart for sharing this!

A-Body is a very translucent, foggy, amber hue with a slight pinkish tint to it. Pours with a fizzy one finger white head that fades pretty quickly.

S- Nose is good and complex. The highlights are slightly tart raspberries and a big acidic sourness. Also noticeable are a hint of vinegar, a slight sweetness, and bready yeast.

T-Flavor is quite tart and offers slightly tart raspberries and a big acidic sourness with a nice bready yeast backbone. A hint of raspberry sweetness comes through for the finish which is a culmination of the initial flavors with an added salty component.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2013 Re-rate 7/14/13: Bottle sample at a sour tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks kerenmk. Vintage 2010. Lovely red color with a big frothy pink head. Wonderful powerful barnyard aroma with lots of raspberries, some sweaty touches and fruit skin notes. Sour and delicious flavor full of raspberries and wild yeast. Medium-bodied. Magnificent. 9/4/9/4/18=4.4

Bottle from my cellar at a tasting. Vintage 2005. Clear red color with a pinkish head. Aroma of barnyard, manure, lots of raspberries and some sweaty notes. Sour flavor of raspberry, oak, yogurt notes, a bit of vinegar, some citrus and a bone-dry finish. Wonderful. 8/4/8/5/17=4.2

Small pink head. Bright red body. Leathery barnyard and horse blanket aroma with metallic old hop notes. Sour-astringent metallic wooden raspberry taste with notes of I cant really say what. Thin-bodied. Sharpish mouthfeel. Dry-acidic wooden barnyard and cheese aftertaste with lemony notes. Very nice and refined. (0.75l bottle at Håndverkerstuene, Oslo.)

At a tasting , 2005 vintage, many thanks DSG, small head, quite hazy light reddish colour with pinky streaks, aroma of raspberry, hedgegrow, brussel sprouts and manure, strong vinegary sourness with a strong raspberry presence in the back serving as a backbone without overwhelming the beer leading to a wonderfull fruity aftertaste. Not easy but extremely satisfying.

2007 bottle. Lot 15/08. Bottled September 14 2009. Took off the cap and there was a bit of seepage over the cork. Still had a nice pop. Light carbonation. Red liquid with light skim and circle of tiny bubble foam. Soft raspberry scent with trace of cheesiness. Kind of like drinking a bottle of wine in the sun. Seems more akin to wine than beer. As you get in the bottle the sourness/tartness picks up. A lot of character comes out of the wood. The bottom of the bottle is the best part, darker fruit notes. The middle is more tart. Dark bitterness is tasty. Not as sour as expected. Raspberry, cheese and wood.
Deep red color and rich flavor. The barrel aging seems to dampen the sourness of the raspberries, making this smoother than other raspberry lambics.

Bottle at a tasting: hay, damp and moist forest, respberries, leaves, sour cream, strong acidity, manure, very light sweetness in the background, yeast, great mouthfill, very rich and long after taste, a bit hard to drink but enjoyable.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2013 Bottle sample at a sour tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks kerenmk. Pours an amazing red with a pink head, bursting aroma of raspberries, brett, nice acidity, fresh leaves and some manure, flavor is delicate with raspberries, green tea, lemon acidity, vinegar, extremely tasty, full bodied, outstandingly delicious 10/5/9/5/16[4.5] 

@ a tasting. thanks DSG, pours cherry red color with some orange taints and medium slightly pinkish head, lively aroma of lemon juice, wet leaf, rotten vegetables and some forest fruit acids the flavor is really dry with some cheese water, lime, wood and some none sweet forest fruit juice, zesty mouthfeel, powerful long lasting finish, full body. Amazing 9/5/9/5/16[4.4]

750 ml corked bottle. A hazy deep red beer with a small, fizzy, fully diminishing pink head. The aroma is moderrately yeasty and lightlòy malty with very strong notes of raspberries, and other notes of wood, funk and earth. The flavour is lightly to moderately sweet, heavily acidic. The raspberries presence is strong and delicious. Medium body, lively carbonation, long finish with light bitterness. Obvoiusly very astringent, tart and sour, but balanced, and with lots of raspberries. Good.

750 ml corked and capped bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 5%. Made with 300 g of raspberries per liter beer. Clear signal red colour, moderate pink head. Intense aroma of raspberries (no surprise). The flavour is very sour with notes of lemons and raspberries, fairly dry and crisp.

Vintage 2005, shared at RBWG 2010.  Whoa buddy, the aroma on this is straight up old white cheese and sour.  The flavor is extremely sour with hints of raspberry and sour... extremely sour. Whoa.  Possibly a bad bottle or just one that didnt age well... hard to say.
Pours a red color with no head. The taste is soursweet, fruity with loads of sour raspberry flavors. Finshes slight sour and balanced. Light dry palate.

Bottle says 2005; cork says 2007.  Pours murky copper into a tumbler. Head quickly subsides to nothing. Sour raspberry and barnyard aromas. Sour patch cheese upfront turning to tart sour raspberry in the dry lasting finish.

Pours a deep, bright red with a small quickly dissipating pink head. The aroma has some funky sour notes and some fruity sweetness. The flavor brings a bracingly tart start. Then a fruity refreshing finish. Very, very good.

Pours a vibrant cherry red with a pink head. Nose is vaguely fruity, almost reminds me of fruit punch or Beaujolais or something, nothing too overwhelming - but the taste packs quite a whallop! Tart, fresh and lively, this reminds me of eating berries off the bush as a child. The characteristic lambic sourness is present, and really helps to keep the massive amount of fruit in check. Lovely!

Now this is a great looking brew. A full, red color, like they used more of the raspberries than in other, similar fruit-lambics. Acidity is at an acceptable level. Well-balanced, fruity and very enjoyable!

Thanks turdferguson for sharing.  2007. Pours a vivid ruby with two fingers of a crackling pink head. Nose shows a nice fruity sweetness, raspberry for sure, some spice, nice mix of funky barnyard elements and some acidity. Flavor is a fantastic balance of acidity and fruit elements, pie spice, mild perceived sweetness, clean tartness. Very sessionable acidity  with some fruit on the finish.

Bottle, vintage 2007.

Really good looking ruby red with a small pink head. Mild aroma of fresh raspberries, grass and funk. Not as tart as a "normal" Cantillon. Very dry and pleasant taste of raspberries, grass, funk and wood. Tart but not too tart. Very drinkable with a perfect carbonation. A very good lambic. I want an other bottle!
2005 bottle, pours light pink with a off white head.  Heavy sour cheese aroma.  Super funky and not in a good way.  Moldy cheese, dirty diapers.  Perhaps a bad bottle.

750ml bottle.  Dark reddish brown with a thin white head.  Very sour nose that hits you as soon as its poured, with less pronounced aromas of slightly sweet raspberry skin.  Taste start off dominated by sour sour raspberries, fading into extremely acidic raspberry skin.   The acidity in this one is a bit much for me.

750ml (thanks to mrkanable) with 2005 on the neck and a bottling date in 2007. i was excited about this beer but the moment I smelled it I was disappointed. I have never smelled a beer this bad and I love funky lambics. This was not cheesy, it was not barnyard, it was not even horse-piss. This was rancid and putrid garbage. I think this was the worst beer I have ever smelled. The beer looked good, it was a cloudy reddish color. The taste was oddly pretty good despite the vomit and trash smell. I tasted funky lambic and raspberries like I expected. This was alsoa little more acidic that I would like but the smell is what killed the experience. I need to get a fresh bottle.

Thanks Bill.  2006 vintage.  The beer pours to a nice murky purple body with a thin white head.  The aroma is raspberry fruit and leaves.  Some light straw or hay. 2006 Vintage Pours an almost pinkish red color w/ a small white head minimal lacing.  Expected sweet from the appearance but didnt find it in the aroma. 2001 vintage, bottled in 2002.  Huge thanks to alfrantzell for breaking this awesome S.O.B. out on his birthday.  Pours a cloudy reddish color with a nice off-white head that fades to a ring and spotty foam.  Aroma is very funky and tart, with a lot of raspberry and just a tiny bit of acetone/nail polish. UPDATED: JAN 21, 2014 Bottle 750 ml, thanks to Fred. Appearance is amazing red with pink head. Aroma is very wild; musty mushrooms come first, then you get some fruits. Finally re-rating this. Bought a fresh bottle at Cantillon a few weeks ago, hoping it would be closer to all the marvel I experienced drinking rose de gambrinus. Well, it does. Beautiful clear red pour with pink head. Aroma of intense raspberry juice, light leafiness, mild Cantillon funk. Taste is quite sour, raspberry juice, Cantillon, funky, cheesy notes. A: 2002 Vintage.  The pour is almost red rose in color with almost no head despite a fairly vigorous pour.

S: The raspberries have certainly begun to fade, but they are still very noticeable. The fruit provides a slight sweetness to the nose which nicely offsets the very acidic and tart aromas.

T: This beer is extremely acidic and doesnt have quite the fruitiness left to balance this out (but this is what you expect from Cantillon). The oak is not all that present, but there is certainly a dryness from both the wood and the fruit.

M: Due to the lack of carbonation, the beer is quite slick and smooth on the palate. The high acidity and overall tannic quality of the beer gives a very dry finish.

D: I would like to try this beer again, perhaps in a fresher state. This is certainly a very nice lambic, even with a fading fruit character.

Bottle 2005 with courtesy of plovmand. 
Pours beautifully red with a pink head and nice lastings. 
A dry raspberry and woody flavour hits the nose, with hints of dirt. 
Nice dry and sour raspberry flavour with notes of oak and grape. 
Lovely dry sour raspberry finish.

Bottle. 2005 edition. The body is hazy dark reddish with a creamy longlasting pink head. Sour raspberries, acid, barnyard and wood. Nice acidic flavour with lots of raspberries and wet wood. Tart and musculus sour  raspberry finish. Extremely well balanced. Perfectly carbonated.

25 oz bottle, 2005 vintage.  Pours a mostly clear reddish pink body on first pour with a fizzy pink tinged head that settled fairly quickly.  The nose is as funky and complex as you would expect from Cantillon, very dry with some acetic raspberry vinaigrette notes, light wood, cobwebs, and a little stinky feet. Appearance is thick red with a small white/pink head. Aroma of funk and raspberries. Taste is sour but still sweet with a clear taste of raspberries. This is an amazing complex but still refreshing beer, one of the best Ive tasted from Cantillion.

Great tart acidic and bright raspberry flavor, again, like the Kriek, its not too abrasive, fairly dry.   Thinner feeling body in a delicate way, fine soda carbonation, nice.

Thanks to buffalohead for sharing a 2005 vintage of this at a tasting.  Even after a dozen other beers the Cantillon goodness shone through. UPDATED: JAN 15, 2010 Vintage 2008 with craftycarl21 and WLG423. Deep pink hued garnet with a small light pink head. Aroma is bursting with fresh pureed raspberry, a light acidic funk, a light oak note, and tart over ripe nectar. Flavor is suitability tart and wholly rude. Tart raspberry, wood, and a massively sour funk kick you right in the Jimmie. A mild acetic acid peeps in as well to allow for a nice warming on the way down. Balance of flavors is superb: sour kick, raspberry tartness, funk and wood all combine to make for quite the quaff. Palate is mildly effervescent, slippery, smacking, and finished quite dry. Absolutely incredible. Vintage 2007 Re-rate. Pours a beautiful ruby-garnet with a lively pink head that expediantly dissipates with an audibly lively fizz. What is left is a thin pink hued veneer that sticks to the edges of the glass, with numerous tiny bubbles rising up from various nucleation points. The aroma is powerful and pronounced in an nasal burning, Cantillon-typical rude fashion. I love it. Raspberry puree abounds, as does pear and apple cider. These cider notes intermingles with the slightest acetic acid note to make for a mild vinegar quality. The BJCP says this acetic acid profile is undesirable, and I think theyre full of shit. Gratuitous earth, funk, farm manure, and oak are all decidedly prevalent. The first sip brings about the laceratively rude qualities Ive come to love from Cantillon: Huge funk and puckering sourness is only slightly tamed by raspberry and further cider notes. A slight tannic oak melds into a swirling torrent of goat and horse balls- a desirable quality indeed. The palate is incredible for the style: a nice full weight sits on the tongue, complemented nicely by a pillowy effervescence. The mouthfeel is slippery as the quaff takes place, and finishes bone dry and super attenuated. Perhaps the best framboise in my book- second only to Hommage- but I guess that a hybrid would be cheating...

Light burgundy pour with a small, light pink head. Aroma huge with tart fresh raspberry, funk, and some subtle notes of the oak aging. Palate starts with the tartness from the raspberry, then does a deceptive cadence into a big sour kick, rather than the expected drop into the finish. Once the finish comes, it mellows out into a nice dry mouthfeel. Excellent fruit lambic.

pours out a deep pinkish red with no head.  aroma has notes of raspberry and funk, slight hints of alcohol come out through the aroma.  Woody notes are mostly hidden by the strong fruity aroma. Dark pink pour with fizzy pink head..."punch your mother" sour...great citrus notes...wonderful

Deep pinkish reed with a small pink foam on top. Very strong, deep and fruity rasberry aroma with light woody notes. Fruity, slightly acidic, woody and funky flavour with a extremely dry woody finish. Lovely.

Vintage 2005. forgotten where from..  hazy dark red brown pinkish colour, with a rapidly disappearing pink head. sour fruit nose of raspberry, wood and grapefruit. fresh and light mouthfeel, with a gentle sparkle and delicate mouthwatering sourness. lovely bubbly sour goodness. bathtub material!!!

nice pinky red  pour with a white head. Beautiful aroma of tart rasberries. Flavor is tart rasberies. Very fresh and fruity. Nice and dry with a lasting sourness. Very tart and refreshing.

2006 bottle shared by corby112 at cdc release. Pour is pinkish red with a fizzy white head. Aromas of tart funk and raspberries. Flavor is mouth puckering with raspberries, sour funk, and a slight sweet candy flavor. Amazing sour here but slightly overpriced...
