2002 bottle.  Ruby-copper pour with a little white head.  The aroma is a touch earthy, and damp wood with notes of raspberry, cherry and cranberry with some sour lacto and a little brett.  Massively sour cherry and raspberry with some oak,  vinegar and grassiness.  Medium-thin body with a prickly carbonation and very dry finish.

On tap @ Belmont Station in a snifter, pours out a deep clear red with a large fluffy pink head. A nice fresh raspberry aroma. Flavor is initially tart fresh raspberries like when I was a kid and didnt know which ones to pick off the vine then the tartness hits you. As the beer disappeared the raspberries faded further and the tart lemon and green apple came forward. This was by far the best framboise lambic that I have ever had.
Sweetish raspberry nose, nice sourness. Light reddish body, small head. Very sour flavor, but nice sweetness from the fruits.

Bottle thanks to my man dchmela.  Dave is the best.  Finally shared this with my friend Nate, trying to convince him of the amazingness of sour beers.  Pours orange/pink, hazy and with a minor light pink head.  Sour funky aroma, with lemon, acetic vinegar notes, a bit of raspberry, and some nice wood.  Similar taste with a nice puckering finish.  Bottle was 5 years old, so the raspberry was faint.  I love it.
On tap at Brouwers Seattle Beer Week Sour Fest.  Pours cloudy magenta with a small pink head.  Funky, tart raspberry aroma.  Very sour.

Bottle, thanks to Jimbowood.  Label says 2003.  Cloudy orange / brown pour with no head.  Aroma is vinegar, salty tomatoes, and some funkiness.  Flavor is the same, pretty dang sour, and not very fruity at all.  A little bit of a watery palate, and vegetable / tomatoe saltiness noticeable as well.

750ml bottle. Pours a ruby red with a pink head. The aroma has some light sulfur notes with some strong berry at the end but huge barnyard funk notes with alot of acidity on the nose. Flavor is mouth puckering sour up front. Quite acidic but not overly so, lots of woody oaky notes towards the end with a slight lingering note of fresh berries. Not as good as the Kriek but still fantastic. Much more sour than the Gueze and the Kriek.
like others, this sour is better masked as a tart fruit (in this case raspberry). lightly carbonated and fizzy. only for the hardcore.

The aroma is sour and funky with some raspberries. The appearance is deep red with a pink head. The flavor is like the aroma. The palate is thin but right for the style. Overall this is not enjoyable for me.

2005 vintage, bottled 2007.  Dark ruby red body with a short pink creamy head that slowly fades to a mist.  The aroma is strongly tart and funky, some hay, dust, vinegar, and rhubarb.  A mellow sweet raspberry aroma comes through middle to end.  Heavily sour and acidic.  Very vinegar like with only slight fruit noticeable in the middle.  Finishes with a strong funky sour.  I was hoping for a bit more fruit along with the tartness, but this is by far the sourest beer Ive ever tasted and I love it.

Small pink head does not last long good carbonation bubbles lining upthe glass in a pink salmon coloured franboise aroma raspberries vinegar vinous other fruit flavour bitter grape and vinegar raspberries acidic taste apple gives the palate a numbness plenty of fizz and acidity want to like the taste of these ales but can takejust so much of them finish acidic fruity big fizz mellows down though

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2010 2001 Vintage, consumed Sept, 11th, 2010 at a good friends wedding. Age has not affected this brew whatsoever. The cork was a disgusting rotting mess, but the liquid inside was fantastic. Lots of fruit, subtle acidity, and perfect mouthfeel. Poured with a nice bright pink head, and itreally was a perfect way to start the night. Congratulations Jonathan!

2005 Vintage, shared with myself on Mothers day. Translucent pink pour with a quickly diminishing pink head. Aroma of jammy, out of season raspberries, seeds and typical lambic funk. Flavor is a delicate montage of earthy notes, sour raspberries, and a bit of citrus. Delightfully dry, effervescent finish.

On tap at Novare Res.
Pours a bright pink/red with a white pinkish head.  Aroma is sour raspberries, funky yeast, barnyard, and yogurt.  Flavor is pretty much the same, sour dry and raspberries.  Nice fruit lambic!
Bottle from 2005. Pours red with a white head. Taste is sour, funky, dry, lightly acidic. Very drinkable and enjoyable.

Thanks to the Cheeseman for this (I think) 2002 Vintage.  Pours a golden pink color.  Aroma is sour and funky with a little bit of soap in there.  Wow, this is damn sour. I like the sourness, but the strange acidity from the cherries is a little too much for me.  This is exceptional, as are most Cantillon brews, but I cant drink that much of it.

2003 vintage.  Pours a nice reddish color with a medium sized white head.  The aroma is a strong sour cherry aroma with lots of funkiness behind it.  The mouthfeel is medium to thin with good carbonation for this style--not too highly carbonated.  The taste is a big sour fruit taste with plenty of vinuous notes, heavy oak, and herbal flavors as well.

Bottled 2001, Pours a pinkish red hue with a fizzy this white head, almost like a soda.  Nose full of dry grass, berries, and old damp wood funkiness.  The brightness lights up my tongue with a sharp deep sour pucker with notes vinegar, reduced red wine, fresh raspberries and blackberries and some funky farmhouse hay, grass, and wood.  The depth of the funk really builds as the beer warms with notes of sour hard cheese, and horseblanket.  The fruit turns tart in the aftertaste and a residual sour dryness is left behind.  Delicious.
This was an amazing treat!! Just as mspindler said it, I felt like I was back in my Grandmothers kitchen!

2006 Bottle shared with NickTheElder at the Back Abbey.  Pours a murky purplish red with a cotton candy head.  Aroma is like a slap in the nose.  TONS of funk, barnyard, barrel, and some red wine.  But under all that is this awesome sweet fruitiness that NickTheElder described as his grandmothers berry cobbler.  Flavor is just as big and complex, starting with a nice sharp sourness and a blast of raspberry and funk, then smoothing out nicely and finishing with oak and red wine.  Finish is dry and clean and doesnt hang around for long.  Medium bodied with not too much carbonation.  Better than I thought a framboise could be.

2003, pretty awesome stuff.  These things can age for 20 years like they say on the bottle.  great aroma, sourness is strong but once the palate intigrates its perfect.  super finish.  lots of wood / oak and funk.  cool part was the last bit of sludge smelled and tasted exactly like a fresh rasberry.  outstanding beer with lots of upside as it ages I think.  bought a while back at Holiday in escondiz for $26

Bottle 2006: Bright red pour with adense pink ring of head. Outrageously funky aroma! Cork, cobweb, horse blanket, leather, barnyard, tannic notes, acidic, tart raspberry notes are detectable under the wild fermentation greatness. Crisply acidic body- fairly low carbonation. Lots of funky wildness in the flavor as well. Farmhouse, leather, sharp citric acidity, some sulfuric character as well. The raspberry presence remains tart & harmonious with the base lambic. Some old woody notes, with a light tannic character that leads into the clean finish. Complex, funky, sour, stellar!

750ml corked bottle. Vintage 2006, BB December 2018.
Served lightly chilled in pilsner flute.
Pours a vibrant purple-tinged ruby body, slight haze, with a couple of fingers worth of dense pink mousse.
Plenty of fruit comes through on the nose; tart raspberry, ripe strawberry, some red plum, citrus rind, with an unmistakeable touch of typical Cantillon vinegar and funk. Particularly woody/oak, more like a young dry red wine than other examples ive come across.
As expected, a big acid component on the palate straight up, bit more balanced with the fruit this time around. Mouthfilling texture, lively carbonation, very lengthy yet dry.
Delicious fruits on the body; raspberry and strawberry jam, redcurrant jelly, vinous plum and blackberry, grapefruit and lemon cuts through leading onto vinegar and citric acidity. Hay and subtle horse towards the finish. Ends with big lingering acid, tannic and oaky.
Would have to put this on par with the best fruit lambics im yet to try. Certainly the better of the raspberry(framboise) ive come across.

750ml bottle of 2006 vintage. Poured opaque cherry red, like fruit punch,with a thin pink head that quickly dissipates. Aroma was of vinegar, raspberry, some strawberry sweetness, hay, raw wheat, woody vanilla, citrus, and funky hop and yeast aroma. Flavor was sweet and tart grapefruit-raspberry, sweet citrus around the sides of the tongue, tart strawberry fructose, raw wheat, subtle funky yeast, and a strong tart finish. Very bubbley champagne like carbonation, very strong and enjoyable flavor, but a lot of vinegar on the palate.

OHHH another Lambic.  Why do I do this to myself.  A gift from a new friend actually, very thoughtful.  I wonder if this friendship will also sour with warming (joke).  It was a nice looking beer but strong the vinegar overtones were nasty liek eating easter eggs while dieing them.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: 2005 Vintage, 2007 bottling, bottle dated August 20, 2007.  Pours a light red-orange with a thin lasting cover of pinkish white foam.  Oak aroma, vinegar, funk, and a slight fruitiness, a bit of plastic aroma in there that detracts.  Taste is fantastically sour, raspberry pulp , and a light oaky finish.

Aroma was full of raspberry seeds as well as cantillon funk, slight vinegary note with some wood and barnyard.  poured a reddish purple with similarly colored head.  Flavor was excellent, jammy raspberry with lots of seed notes, refreshing sourness, citrus, oak, and vinegar.  lean bodied, with nice carbonation.  Excellent.

750ml Bottle (2006 Vintage):  Tart aroma of tart fruit, light funk, raspberries, and oak.  Poured fire engine red/slight magenta in color with a small, fizzy, red head that disappeared immediately.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and medium to heavily sour.  Tastes of sour fruit, raspberries, light funk, oak, wood, and some citric acid.  Light to medium body.  Smooth, lightly thin texture is dry.  Average carbonation.  Tart, raspberry and oak finish lingers and causes salivation.
Poured cranberry red in color with a medium pinkish head. Smelled of vinegar and fruit. Tastes like a lambic should. Nice and sour with a hint of raspberry through the finish. Really nice brew.

Tap @ Green Dragon...  Poured a cloudy red with a thin white head.  Aroma of fruity wine and tart berries.  Super dry palate and felt like champagne in my mouth.  Played mostly like a tart sour ale while the raspberries werent present until the finish.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2016 Red with a small white head. Intense raspberry aroma, with leather and hay, and a hint of barnyard. Dry and tart raspberry flavour. Five months after bottling, this is intense, fruity and tart. Not for aging...... Re-rate, 2011 bottle on new years eve 2016. I was wrong. Its fabulous. Pleasant raspberry aroma with plenty of funk including some cellar notes and medicinal notes. Dry and tart flavour with raspberry and definite Cantillon character.

Tap. Pours with a red color and a faint reddish head. Aromas of raspberry and some lemon perhaps. Flavor is complex, sour, tart raspberries, complemented by some toastiness and wood. fairly well carbonated and good smooth palate. Definitely something special.

2006 Bottle. Pours with a very pink head over a pink hazy body. Good lacing. Aroma is straight real raspberries, right down to the seed and the little hairs that come out of them. Some wood and earth notes as well. Taste is sour, but not quite as puckering as the Kriek (regular Cantillon Kriek, not the Lou Pepe). Really nice with real, fresh, amazingly well captured raspberries. Very puckering, tart and dry. Goes quite well with dark chocolate!

Wow! Another amazing Lambik!
Pours a red hue with absolutely no head!
Aroma is of rasberries, cherries, and a hint of yeast - not much though. 
Sour flavor with lots of tropical fruits within the flavor as well. Beer has a lightly tarty ending to it as well!
Great tasting beer!
Medium texture with light carbonation.

2004 Bottle on 11/30/2008 at the 3rd Annual Richmond Industry Gathering. Very hazy deep amber body with a small slightly pink head. Sweet raspbery and sour aroma. Big sour flavor with light raspberry notes. Light body with high carbonation.

2001 vintage from Friar Tucks in Savoy, IL. Pours amber with some pale pink hues and an off white head, spotty lacing. Lacto/Brett aroma that comes across with notes of vinegar, mildew, lemon, and hay- not inviting but not offensive either. Typical Belgian lambic texture and mouthfeel, which is soft with a fine effervescence. First sip just socks you with a huge mouth puckering sourness. Its almost too intense for me at first, but like jumping in cold pool, you get used to it after awhile. Raspberry is merely a nuance with the age on this and the bugs taking over. There is some slight acetic (vinegar) notes, but it sort of adds to the complexity. Finish is musty, moderately acidic and somewhat dry. A good beer for its style, but just a bit too sour for my personal tastes.

6 oz drafts poured on tap at Binnys South Loop (Chicago, IL). Matching flutes for the couple as we experience this together. Pours a reddish brown highly hazed with minimal white head. Aromas are funky and oaky up front, light sourness with subtle raspberry on the nose. Initial is tart and oak, light bodied with a subtle funkiness, sour tart finish that sticks to the palate and I enjoy very much. Nice raspberry and oak with sour that isnt overwhelming, but affirms its presence. Very quaffable. Complex. Cheers!

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2012 Bottled at Horsens Beerfestival. Hazy pink body with a small pink head. Nice aroma of sour raspberry, and mould. Flavor is refreshing sour, citric fruit, raspberry and wood. Complex, tart and wonderful balanced.

Bottle, vintage 2004.  Pours a deep red with a small white head.  Aroma is quite funky with lots of old socks, blood (maybe a metallic aroma?), and a fruity tinge.  Flavor of tart sourness, more funk and metallic notes, bandaid, and tons of yogurt.  Like all Cantillons, super sour and hard to drink.  I wasnt crazy about the flavors in this one, especially in comparison to other lambics.  
7/4/7/3/15 (3.6/5)

Bottle, vintage 2004, bottled 2006. Aroma quite funky with sweat, cheese, lemon, barnyard, pineapple. Raspberry jam there as well, but always very funky raspberry jam, very much melded with the base beer. Some strawberry/strawberry-mango notes in there as well. Flavor has more distinct sweet raspberry but is also bitingly tart, acidic, and sour, maybe in that order, maybe not. In short, glorious.
From a bottle poured a hazy purplish color with lots of head.  Nice tart raspberry flavor with a lingering funky finish.

On tap at the Map Room. 2006. Tart, funky acid and raspberrys. A bit cheesy, but nicely sour and tart. Wheaty, silky, and straw-like. Pours a vibrant, clouded raspberry jam red. Rim of rose. Raging citric acid, french raspberry jam, and searing lactic acid. Bright, fresh, flashing acidity with clean backends. For such a funky nose, the raspberry melds with the acid and the alcohol for really graceful detail.

2003 bottle, aged five years.  The lightly hazy, pinkish-red body shows a small, swirly, off-white film at the surface.  Very little spotty lacing marks the glass.  The beautiful nose shows notes of both fresh, ripe, semi-sweet raspberries and dry, aged, tart ones.  Mildly musty farmhouse yeast notes are accompanied by dry French oak and ample citric acidity.  Flavors show more of the same, an excellent balance between sweet and tart raspberries on full display.  There is citric intensity, along with dry, dusty, tannic elements, but the soft oak and subtle fruity sweetness are enough to smooth things out nicely.  Medium bodied and dry, the sourness really hints the glands in the back of the throat on the way down.  This is a masterful beer, and it is probably the best framboise lambic I have had to date.

2003 draft at Brouwers Big Wood Seattle 2008. Sweet nose of a fruit roll-up. Rosey pink body with a raspberry-pink head unlike anything ive ever seen. Way more tart than the sweet aroma suggested, and the rich fruitiness and sweet are nicely topped by a wealth of sour. Well balanced, very refined and dryish finish. Remarkable.

2003 version, on draft at Brouwers Big Wood 08. Pours a reddish copper with - no joke - a light pink head. The aroma is a burst of fruit, though slightly artificial  like fruit roll-ups. Theres a great tartness showing through, but on the whole its very sweet. The flavor brings the tartness to the forefront, making the fruit seem far less artificial. Like not-quite-ripe raspberries were crushed in a glass  Ive never had a beer that tasted so much like real fruit. Just enough sweetness to offset the tart raspberries. A treat, for sure.
Purple haze with light head.  Aroma of sour fruit.  Full-bodied, cheek-sucking driness.  Superb.

[Bottle] 2005 vintage. Pours a clear pinkish red with a very small whitish head. Aroma is tart raspberries and a bit of barnyard funk and mustiness. The flavor is extremely tart and sour, a touch of acidity, loaded with fresh, tart berries, and some funkiness. Leaves a great sour raspberry finish that lasts quite a while. Awesome.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2008 Un altro splendido lambic alla frutta di Cantillon, la Lou Pepé Framboise è meno intensa e più beverina della kriek, ma nellaroma di frutta fresca e nel sapore acidino e vinoso si rende un ottimo aperitivo pronto a soddisfare i palati più scettici ed esigenti. Quasi. cul

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2010 Sampled on draft at Zenos in State College PA this beer poured a dark red color with a small white head that faded quickly. The aroma was strong tart berry. The flavor was extremely tart, sour and bitter  with hints of berry and an intense long tart and sour finish. Interesting.

Dark red colored with little pink head. Bubblegummy raspberry dominates aroma sour lemon. Crispy palated with lots of raspberries and sweet sourness, aftertaste has bubblegum lasting with dry wood. Again, no chance to disappoint to brewery.

750 mL bottle, vintage 2004.  Poured ruby red with thin pink head.  Appeared slightly undercarbonated.  Nose consisted of tart raspberry and lemon.  Very sour, acidic raspberry flavor.  A bit thin.  Slightly disappointed by this one.

Brown color with faint head but one of the best raspberry aromas I’ve ever had the pleasure of encountering.  As sour as the average Cantillon (i.e. delicious) and every vintage I’ve had has been very fruity and sour.

On tap at Moeder Lambic. Bright ruby-red color with bubbly pink head. Nose is intense, fresh raspberry with lemony backdrop. Fairly tart flavor balanced by an impression of light sweetness from the fruit. Soft in the mouth with subtle acidity felt more in the belly than on the tongue. Beneath the complexity it was just flat-out tasty. A mind-blower, frankly.

This was the clear winner in a head to head with a lou pepe kriek.  The kriek looked better, but this was better in every other way.  It is kind of an ugly brown color, but big raspberry aroma with yeast and sourness.  Sour flavor as well, but the raspberry has held up remarkably well considering the age.  Intensely sour flavor, and loads of raspberry.

Poured from a 750 ml bottle, vintage 2001.  Thanks Joe!  Fleshy, muddy, rusty red hue.  Seedy acerbic raspberry aroma; alternately soft on stems and musty grass, and violent, on peppery funk; still dominant in that raw, sharp wooden acid character; rustic and rough.

Cutting, fresh raspberry flavor is sharply imbued with funk and minerals, though the fruit still seems impressively lively and evocative; the minerals, firey woods and acetic acids provide wildness and puckering punch never shrinking back, but naturally rich tartness of the fruit is what’s really the centerpiece, and it’s a beautiful, visceral experience.  The vinegar acidity and puckering wooden heat grows more punchy mid-palate.

Still, the body is sumptuous and full, more diverse and more versatile than other high-acid examples; a typical, flaming acidic finish showing lengthy raspberry flesh and seeds; not immensely dry, but satisfying.  The best non-gueze I’ve had from Cantillon; a clean, refreshing example that still has all the outrageousness you could ask for from a lambic.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2013 Bottle from my friend Eric.  Pours a nice ruby color with a frothy head. Aromas of berries and funk. Flavor is just pur vinegar, sour yeast and sour berries.  I am not a sourhead and wont be any time soon.  No sir.

Well Im now a sourhead and love this beer. Old rate 3.1--lol.

2005 vintage on label, cork is stamped bottled 2007. Clear cherry juice color with a fleeting pink head. Big tart, barnyard funk, wood lemon aromas. Light / medium body.  Hugely tart, saliva inducing mouthfeel at first fades some as your tongue goes numb. Very good flavors of woody raspberry seed with tart raspberry pulp and lemon and dry toasted wood. Stays nicely acidic throughout, and thankfully no aspirin burn on the way down. Simply awesome.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 2003 version [vintage 2005]. Hazy red with a grey head that disapears quickly. What strikes me most in this beer is the aroma. It’s so intense, full of raspberries, sourness, acidic notes and wood. The flavour is sour and acid - like a combination of grapefruit and vinegear. But then again it is Cantillon - so I’m not surprised by a soar throat after one glass.

Bottle 75 cl from 2001.Vintage  This bottle have been putted away for some time in a dark and cool celler - very good idea...
The pour is golden redish with a tiny off-white head. The nose is crazy and fantastic full of the sweet rasberrys bot also notes of sweet gasolin. The aging have made this one more friendly, more round and relaxed but still with the sour snakebite that normally caracterise Cantillons beers. Strong rasberry-taste that isw both sour and fruity with a creamy smooth feeling.
Thx for sharing Mikkel

Draught @ Ebenezer’s, 2005 vintage. Pours a clear bubbly red with a very pink fizzy head. Aroma is a slightly tart, dry rasberry, hint of fruity sweetness. Very tart, sharp, with rasberry emerging after initial shap vinegar tartness. Finish is lightly sour, with a faint rasberry exhale. Very carbonated, crisp, light bodied. Delicious.
UPDATED: SEP 17, 2014 75cl, Vintage 2011, exclusive brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex sour fruit brew, balanced, hazy, nearly no head, very good brew, but expensive!

2001 Vintage Bottle.  Thanks to BDR for sharing this.  Cloudy, dark orange pour, little head, with visible milky sediment.  Intense aroma of raspberry.  Flavor is very tart, plenty of raspberry.  Quite acidic.  Excellent stuff!
2005 vintage shared by BrianK at Courtney’s  BBQ.  Pours a pink red puree with a white top.  Raspberry, earthiness, funk, sour patch, lemon acidy.  Incredible lambik.  Went back for seconds and 3rds.

2001 vintage, bottled sample. Translucent pink-gold in colour, with spritzy carbonation. Aromas of raspberry, rose, funk, earth, and nettles. Flavors consist of more raspberry, lemon zest, and a bit of lactic funk on the finish. Wickedly acidic! It practically burned going down, but was so refreshing and tasty. Near perfect for someone like me who cant get enough sour/acidic flavors. Im going to need to track down more of this stuff.

(bottle sampled at Heritage Liquors tasting) Pours dark red with a white head.  Aroma is very strong with raspberry, some hay, and funk which, aside from the raspberry, are all typical from Cantillon.  The taste is also very typical of all Cantillon beers, with a large amount of upfront sourness, but theres this very well done undertone of raspberry that really sets this beer at a level above other Cantillons Ive tried.  Medium mouthfeel with a lingering sour/raspberry seed finish.
Big Raspberry smell ....but wait! At first sip there is no raspberry, just a sharp sour funkiness then a mouthful pof fresh raspberries...very impressive!

2001 Vintage.  Bottle graciously shared by piscator.  What a treat!  Pours a beautiful rose colour, good clarity and one finger head.  Nose- blast of raspberry and lemon zest.  Taste- exceptionally acidic, raspberry of course, citric, and general funk.  Not too dry, nice carbonation. Keeps zinging the pallette long after.. Fantastic!

On-tap at Novare Res, 2005 Vintage served in its proper glass ware 

Poured a crystal clear read with little to no head 

Aromas of raspberries and barnyard funk

Tart and dry flavors of raspberries it reminded me of a raspberry sweet tart with just a slight tingle of carbonation on the tongue 

Very refreshing drink I had this as a desert brew as my wife and kids shopped for me for fathers day I really am getting into these sours as a summertime brew and this brew is one I will be revisiting soon

Big thanks to Pepsican for bonusing me this in a trade.  Poured a hazy dark pink into the glass.  Smelled of funky raspberry and a little wood.  Taste is raspberry, huge funky tartness, and a little wood.  Given that I am just getting into the world of sours, this is my sourest beer to date.  Hard to drink a ton of it, but definitely well made.

Bottle from capones. Dark redish pour with almost not head but lots of carbondaltion on the glass. Aroma is of tart raspberriess and cherries. Taste is perfect sour raspberry with some oak or wook mixed in. I will def be making the trip back to capones to get the kriek. I wish this beer would never end.

2005 (so probably released within the last year). Pomegranate red/orange clear sparkling body, until the last pour when it takes on the opaqueness of some tomato soup. Light rose petal pink head. Aroma of the freshest raspberries, still in wooden crates. More oak influence than typical. Flavor: just a fantastic juicy mouth-puckering old-school hardcore sour Cantillonic lambic with tons of raspberries.

2002 vintage tasted June 6, 2008.  Thanks TimE!  Pinkish in color with large carbonation.  Dry body.  Sweet raspberries, yeast, musty, and vinegar.  Pretty intense flavors.  Extremely enjoyable lambic.

2005 bottle for WeeHeavySDs birthday. Poured a hazy red with a pinkish-white ring. Rich tart yeasty aroma of very sour raspberries. Sour tart taste with the raspberries building up as it goes. Lingering sourness. Very nice lambic.
Beutiful reddish colour. Some hints of raspberries in the nose. Well balanced sourness. Some citrus in the taste. Bottled in a 0.75 l bottle.

Sampled at Heritage Liquors Inauguration beer tasting in Maplewood, Minnesota. Shaed by Joebrew, from a 750 ml bottle pours a dark ruby red and fizzy brew with a thick and fizzy pink head that slowly dissipates to a thin film and off-white ring. Aroma of tart raspberries, barnyard funk, yeast, and a touch of lemon. Taste is spritzy, medium bodied with semi-tart raspberries, citrus zest, some herbal spice and a touch of white vinegar. Finish has a tart berry aftertaste that the carbonation can really do a number to your nose. Another fine fruit lambic from Cantillon

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2008 2005 Vintage; tasted 5/29/08:  Big thanks to Joebrew dishing out this one.  Dark pink color with very little head.  The nose is incredible.  Like jamming your face into a fresh basket of raspberries.  Now smash them with your fist to turn them to juice, and thats pretty much what it tastes like.  Very tart.  You know how some fruit beers are very obviously made with fruit syrup or an extract?  This tasted so loaded with fresh fruit, I swear I could even taste the little seeds on the raspberries.  Lightly soured wheat and malt base helps balance it out.  Very, very good.  2001 Vintage; tasted 7/4/08:  Murky brown color with no head.  Massive raspberry and strawberry aroma.  Tart, very tart fruit taste.  A little hay and wheat.  The raspberry flavor is unbelievable.  I can almost feel the raspberry seeds getting stuck in my teeth.

75 cL bottle, 2005. Pours hazy to murky red with a fizzy pink head. Sulphorish dry raspberry aroma. Quite tart initial flavour. Has a classic dry wooden base flavour with a nice raspberry tartness lingering on top. Ends dry and with a lingering raspberry acidic to citric flavour.

On-tap at Churchills. Pours cloudy red with a fizzy pink head, no lcae. Smells sour and funky and fruity as well. Tastes sour and citrusy lemon with a constant mellow raspberry flavor. Not very sweet raspberry though, just raspberry. Funky sourness to it as well. Medium body, very dry, vibrant carbonation.
(Vintage 2005, Bottle) Ruby red, Small, pink, quickly gone head. Sour nose with hints of raspberry. Acidic palate. Sour taste with rather clear raspberry flavour.
Bottle.05.Pinky red with no head,aroma of apple vinegar and shalots,taste is of tart raspberry,acid,crab apple sherbet fountain and pineapple cubes,long dry finish.

Bottle 2001. Body-orange red with a thick film of bubbles. Nose-big beautiful funk, wet dog, and unsweet red fruits. Taste-dry, light red fruit, white pepper, perfect funk, medium to high acid, watered down lemon juice, citric zest, has a bog flavor of watered down citric juice, words cannot describe the complexity, depth, and wonders of this beer. One of the worlds finest sours.

75cl bottle, labelled 2005. Deep red with pink small head. Very true, slightly sweet raspberry aroma, softly tart but not that complex. Red currants and raspberry on the sharply tart flavor. Slightly puckering tannic finish. Medium bodied, average carbonation. Very authentic and natural raspberry aromas but still with that Cantillon edge. And with one of the most stylish labels Ive seen!

2004(label), 2006(cork) vintage courtesy of Bu11zeye: Poured a deep reddish color lambic with a nice white color bubbly head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of raspberry is dominant with some sour notes as well as some barnyard notes and a weird cough syrup-like finish. Taste is dry with some notes of sour raspberry and some limited acidic notes which I appreciated since I usually find the Cantillon lambic a bit too acid. Full body with some great carbonation. I thought this was really good but I good have done without the weird raspberry syrup-like aftertaste.
Sampled at Hellbillys. Sour and fruity aroma on the nose. Pink body color. Good dose of raspberry and sour flavor. Dry finish on the palate like this syle is. A good lambic.

2005 vintage. Pours a hazed brilliant ruby colour with a whispy pink-tinted head that fades quickly. The nose is tart raspberries, vinegar, wet hay funk and dust. The flavour was extremely tart and sweet with less funk than I anticipated. Vinegar-like acidity and tart raspberries were about all that came to mind in the taste, along with residual sugars. The body was light and the carbonation was gently effervescent. No alcohol was detectable.

WOW! I thought the kriek was good. This beer gets my perfect score. I cant ever give  the top number on anything so this (in my terms) is my tops. Outstanding strong vinegar, sour raspberry and funky aroma. Wet wood and moldy cheese are faint as well. Pour was a beautiful murky red with a thin white ring for a head. Taste was incredibly sour and funky. Tastes like a raspberry/vinegar mix that was left in Grandmas attack for decades and just discovered. Dusty, musty and woody. This is heaven in a bottle.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 2005 bottle shared by shyam at the phx tasting... raspberry colored with brown tints and a whitish pink head which fades quickly to a ring leaving behind some spotty lacing. the aroma is like a damp rotted forest... wed wood, a little funk, canvas, earth, grass and  some raspberry tartness. the palate is nicely tart and dry with very little sweetness. flavors come over from the aroma... some cheesy funk and woody raspberries. it kinda reminds me of raspberry flavored emergenC... medicinal and mineral. medium bodied with a very vibrant mouth feel.

Sampled at Hellbillys tasting.  Thanks Shyam!  Pours a nice red color with a small pinkish head.  Aroma is all raspberry with a bit of funkiness.  Flavor is fruity, but mostly raspberry, with a bit of the funk coming through.  A hint of sourness on the finish.  Good fruit brew.

Sampled at Hellbillys Hellraiser courtesy of Shyam.  THANKS!!!  Musty cut raspberry bushes with a hint of sweaty feet, this one pours crimson with a minimal rose colored head.  Raspberry sourness, citrus, and Maytag blue cheese.  Interesting and flavorful, maybe Im coming around on the style.

poured a pink color with a small head that quickly went away.  A lambics funk aroma with raspberry in the background.  Flavor is similar,  the raspberry is more in the finish with citrus and a mild funk up front.  Not overly sour,  little carbonation.

750ml bottle fully of beer brewed in 2003. Cork says it was bottled in 2005. The batch is at least 4 years old.  The pour is spritzy and lively.  Before it settles, the foam almost appears orangish, but after it settles it looks like orange jello in the flute. A pinkish orange jello.
The aroma is obviously fruity, but there is also a nice tart tickle that hits the back of the nostrils.
The flavor is rich with tart and fruity currents swirling over my tongue. The raspberry is most noticeable in the finish. The tartness is throughout and refreshing. A delicious creation that really excites the drinker with its mystique.

Good lord.  This is by far one of the best fruit lambics I have ever tried.  The initial taste is the funk of a lambic, but it is completely offset by the raspberries, thus leaving no sour aftertaste even though it is very present in the beer.  I dont think it really can get better than this.

05 vintage on tap at beachwood bbq!

great nose that reminds me of the best slushie that I have ever smelled(blue one)

has a wonderful flavor that matches the nose...but with a super nice acid flavor and a perfect amount of funk......great stuff

750 ml green corked and capped bottle poured a clear ruby red with a small lingering pink head. Aromas of raspberry, citrus, light vinegar and a hint of barnyard. Palate was light bodied crisp and tart. Flavors of raspberry, straw, light citrus, light mustiness and a hint of vinegar with a crisp drey lingering tart finish.

750ml bottle had in vegas (so glad i brought this to have with the wife)....bottle dated 09/01/2006.... poured an opque and somewhat cloudy pomegranate red with a rather short-lived thin and wispy bubbly white head..... aromas of musty barnyard funkiness, very tart and vinegary with a nice raspberry fruit component and some stinky cheese thrown in.... very sprite, tart, and refreshing flavors overall.  lively mouthfeel and enhanced by the soft raspberry tones that worked well with this funky beast.

Extremely tart raspberry aroma my jowls are puckering and watering just inhaling it,straight raspberry vinegar saturated wheat,seems like it is going to overpower you,but it quickly smoothes out, acidity so high is burns the bottom nostril area,quite the experience

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2015 Bottle direct from brewery - vintage 2005/bottled in 2007.   Sweet-sour raspberry aroma - light mustiness.  Beautiful ruby red color - slightly hazy with slight head.  Musty, sour raspberry malt flavor - drier than the aroma would lead you to think but raspberry flavor nice and full - excellent vinous features.  Another Cantillon work of art.   Something special for #2000. /2011 - Fresh raspberry, malt, and musty hay aroma.  Hazy ruby red with small head.  Sweet tart raspberry, malt, musty yeast, and dry hay flavor.  Spectacular balance.

2001 Vintage bottle (bottled in 2002).  I was rather underwhelmed (especially for the price).  Aroma is quite barnyard-y with raspberry in the background.  RollinHard really nailed the mustard-y aspect to it.  Flavor reminds one of a red-wine raspberry vinaigrette dressing, quite sour and rather dry.  The beer seems to improve as it breathes over the course of an hour, but it still pales in comparison to the LP Kriek, in my opinion.

Tasted 2008-02-16. 2003 vintage (bottled in 2005?). Pours unclear, red without head. Rather ugly! Aroma: Raspberries, funk, horse blanket. Flavours: Very funky and very tart. Almost no raspberries - tastes more like a geuze than a framboise. Very tart - extremely dry. Pretty tasty!

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2014 Feb - 08. 75cl bottle. 2003 vintage. Pours muddy pink (into my Cantillon stein) with a sprinkly off white head. Aroma is extreme sour, dry, woody, earthy, fruity rasperry. Sprinkly carbonation. Sour tart taste but with a ligh sweet rasperry touch in the end. Funky & Dope! Re-Rate Jan-14. At Cantillon. 2010 Vintage. Lovely intense raspberries, Wood and barnyard. Vague manuer. Elegant. 4-4,3

Poured from a 750ml bottle (2005 vintage) and served in a flute.  This beer poured a hazy, bright red with a tall head of pink, fizzy foam.   The head quickly settled into a thin layer, leaving a small amount of faint lacing.  The aroma of the beer was made up of acidic vinegar, tart rasperries, and also some sweet, fruity yeast esthers.  The flavor inclueded sour raspberries, strong acidity, mild lemon/citrus, earthy yeast, and finished with a dry, puckering sourness that kept building until the glass was empty.  The mouthfeel was light to medium-bodied with light, active carbonation.  A nice blend of fruit and sour.  Very well done.

Pours a hazy, bright red with a pinkish white head that dissipates quickly.  Fruity funk on the nose, you can smell the sour.  Very sour, it really puckers you up.  You dont notice the fruit in this beer as much as you do in the kriek but its there.  Finishes dry and tart.  Nice beer but for my money Ill go with the kriek.
Slightly orange colored pour with a scant head.  Wonderful funky nose with some barnyard.  Very light mouthfeel, actively carbonated.  Huge sour flavor, astringent, sour lemonade.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2009 At the brewery, color was similar to the cherry, but a bit lighter with a fizzy head that lingered. The nose was tart, and the flavor as well, but lacking the complexities of the cherry. Smoother, more mellow and easier to drink, but not as enjoyable.

2001 bottle.  I failed to take notes on the appearance apparantly.  Man, Ive never smelled anything like this before.  Huge sour nose, but it was earthy and dank, lots of mustard notes, some slight berry fruit and a surrounding tartness.  Big sour and mustardy taste, woody, and reminding me of balsamic vinegar, but better.  Unique amongst the few sours Ive had.  This has 6 plus years on it?  Wow, that goes to show I have no idea of the effect of age on lambics.  A bit pungent for me, but damn this was incredibly unique!

Vintage 2001 Huge sour aroma of bright fruit.  Taste is puckeringly sour and bright strawberry.  Finish is bitter and acidic.  Jesus, this is somewhat simple, but fucking amazing.  Beer of the night.
949418

[Shared with Henrik at newyears eve.]
For the first time for more than a year I had problems swallowing the entire bottle of a Cantillon. Was like someone had forgotten it in the cellar letting it maturing for some years more. It didnt get bad, just more challenging. But I wasnt "old" enough.
UPDATED: APR 6, 2008 Lumpfest 08 - 01 bottle.  murky ruby pour.  very sour and acidic on the nose.  very sour and tart on the palate but very good.  this was one of my favorites of the night.

From bottle vintage 2004 -  Pours a dark reddish color, with a half finger of white fizzy, very carbonated head, that dies down pretty quick.  Nose of barnyard, yeast, some country malt, pretty average for a lambic.  Taste is nice, tart, fruity, rasberries.  Palate is medium bodied, astringent, and quiet bitter at the end.  All together very enjoyable lambic.  Helped bring in 2008!

750 bottle purchased at Liquor Max in Loveland, CO.  2005 vintage.  Pours hazy ruby with a small, pink head, mostly diminishing with spare lacing.  Aroma is average malt (straw, hay), light hops (lemon), average yeast (earth, horse blanket) with notes of green raspberries, ripe raspberries, and raspberry skins.  Medium bodied, mineral texture, soft carbonation, and a tart, mouth puckering finish.  Long duration, light sweetness, heavy acidity, and moderate bitterness.  Wow is this one sour!  Yummy!

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2013 750ml bottle shared courtesy of egadzis. Poured a medum and clear reddish color with a small sized head. Aromas and tastes of vinegar, raspberries, berries, and wood. Very tart and puckering finish. 7 3 8 3 15. Rerate ... vintage 2001 drank 10/2013. Nice pucker and raspberries. Increasing the numbers.

750ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki)
Clear crisp raspberry aroma. Slightly perfumed, fruity and acidic taste. Fruity, both raspberry and cherry too. Alas missing a little of the lambic body I like so much.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2008 Bottle @ Svenska Dagar, Pikkulintu, Helsinki. The aroma spreads across the whole room! Wonderful strawberry, raspberry, white wine, sourness and cookies in the aroma. Hazy brown and red colour, medium white-red head. Taste even better and more than lou pepe kriek. Foamy, very dry and tart. Extreme, fruity finish.

2002 bottle @ WSF. Pale reddish orange with no head whatsoever. Candylike aroma with a tart raspberry, strawberry and lemon edge. Taste is much the same, almost like raspberry lemonade, quite puckering with a bit of vinegar in the finish. Tasted how I remember the strawberry patch in the garden smelling.
Hazy light red with small pink head. Sour aroma with hints of rasberries and wood. Flavor full of raspberries, wood and comes out sour. Classic.

Bottled 0,75 ltr, vintage 2000 @Akkurat
Deep cherry red color, small white head. Semi-sour fruity rasberry aroma. Sour Cantillon, extremely fruity mouth-drying rasberry flavor. Sour fruity aftertaste. Another quality lambic from Cantillon. 7 yrs ageing hasnt changed this any worse.

75 cl bottle. Reddish beer with a small head. Aroma of really dry lambic and some raspberries. Very tart and sour in flavor when the yeasts are not blended in, gets smoother and better with the yeasts. Left a small burn in the finish, acidic and fruity on the palate.
Reddish brown of color with a reddish head. An aroma of raspberry, raspberrystones, nice sour and no sweets. A flavor with young raspberries, no sweets, nice sour and stones from raspberry.

25.4 oz bottle, 2003.  Clear but dense ruby with glints of orange and purple.  Light white froth.  Color alone is just amazing, surreal.  A big sour kick in the nose followed by old suitcase, wild raspberries and finally preserves.  An incredible sour-funk-tart-sweet blast leaves me agape after a few sips.  At first tangy fermenting peaches with a woody mushroom funk and cherry pits.  The initial assault on the tastebuds ebbs as mouth-watering raspberry mousse emerges.  Totally wild, yet earthy.  At times this made me cringe and wince but nonetheless compelling.  A psychedelic beer experience.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2011 Lucky enough to drink this from tap at the Bier Circus in Brussels, I liked the Lou Pepe Framboise. The bouquet and body burst with raspberry. Tart but not overly so....that was in what? 2004? Now HFS drinking a 2004 bottle, been in the cellar, its late 2011. This beer is freakin fantastic. The bouquet jumps out of the bottle, its so gorgeous, like total pure raspberry. Then the flavors have just the right amount of fruit acidity, yogurt, and very staid funk, the Cantillon lambic character is just unbeatable, I mean, that dry finish, its nearly perfect. I could drink this day and night, night and day. Love love love.

About a 4oz pour from a 750ml bottle
2004 vintage, consumed Aug, 2007 (3 years cellared)
The bright shiny ruby pink body sits about 60-80% opaque in my glass, with only a small white ring on top that pretends to be a head.  That’s fine, though, and expected.  The rich and deep ruby red hue in the center of the glass loses it’s luminocity as the depth thins near the sides of the glass, which is colored only a soft whitish-pink.  Nose is primarily candied raspberries, doesn’t really have much seed/hair/stem flavors from the fruit, only a slightly sweet fruit scent.  I don’t want to use the term sugary because that would imply a high level of sweetness, and the nose is not very sweet at all, but the raspberry quality is sweet and as much as it pains me to say - underdeveloped, as well.  Only 3 years in the bottle, though, so that’s expected.  You really need these things aged at least 5-6 years for the trademark Cantillon caustic sourness to develop.  Still, I can’t complain too much, because it’s Cantillon and they do gueuze like noone else.  The flavor is interesting, beginning as a creamed, candied raspberry flavor, more of a sugar sweetness than a true fruit sweetness, and over the middle it quickly turns silky smooth and numbing, then quickly turns rough and tingly, even pasty, with some light acetone flavors showing up near the back, then a salty bite at the back of the mouth.  The finish actually does have some seed/hair/stem, moderate tartness, and of course a proper corrosive sourness.  I will need to either find a 1999 or 2002, or put some of this 2004 away for a few more years to rerate.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2007 Bottle. High pink fluffy and quickly disappearing head. Hazy dark red body with a good deal of yeast sediments. Acidic cherries aroma. Powerful acidic raspberries flavor. Low carbonation and a nice long acidic to sour aftertaste. I wonder if iit can be made much better.

Bottle vintage 2003. Pours clearish salmon ruby, delicate pale pink head. Aroma is raspberry, asparagus, oak, bleu cheese. Flavor is sour salty tart raspberry, cheese, vinegar, slight pepper. Very sour.

Corked and capped 750, 2001 vintage. As soon as the rather rusty cap was popped, the center of the cork started bubbling. Strawberry colored pour with a bubbly, light pink head. Sour raspberry nose, barnyard scents. Light, bubbly body. Tart raspberry flavor, mildly sour. Mildly acidic finish. Loved it!

750 ml bottle...2004.  Brilliant red appearance...aroma is loaded with tart raspberries and all those wild fermentation lambic like smells.  Flavor is mostly wood and raspberry while the finish is very sour and grapefruit like.  As far as lambics go, this is pretty good, but Im only good for one glass of this stuff

750mL bottle, 2004 vintage, bottled in 2006.  Pours a brilliant, ruby-red color that fades to pink at the edges of the glass; minimal head that quickly dissipates to nothing.  Very intense, tart aroma, filling the glass: plenty of funk and blue cheese and overripe fruit, with juicy, tart raspberries everywhere; a nice balance of funk and fruit, with some wood and citrus in there as well; complex without being scattered.  Dense, tart raspberries and intense citrus upfront; minimal carbonation, with relaxed acidity compared to most of the Cantillons Ive tasted; very drinkable and complex without losing track of the fresh, tart raspberry character.  Lengthy, tart red fruit finish, showing a little bit of sugar.

A beer to celebrate Belgiums national day. 75 cl bottle, labelled 2003 (though the cork states 2005!) . Beautiful orange -pink colour with an initially huge fine head that even has some pink tones in it.  Aroma: intense raspberry and lemony lambik, wood, even a slight hint of cheese. When it comes to taste, wood and lemony lambik is far more pronounced, though raspberries start the ball. Wood takes over more and more towards the dry finish. Dry mouthfeel, medium to light body, foamy feel. Incredibly complex and refreshing beer. Fruit and wood, raspberry and lemony lambik, all in perfect harmony. I have a hard time deducting any points here.

Thanks to Immy. 750 ml bottle Dated 2001. Pours reddish strawberry in color with white head. Aroma of raspberrys. Taste is SOUR, SOUR and SOUR!!!!!! Raspberries with dry finish. This one will wake-up your taste buds.

Bottle sampled. Pours a transparent red with some haziness and a small pink head. Aroma of acidic raspberries and oak. The flavor is sweet raspberries up front, followed by an acidic tartness. Good brew.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2012 (Bottle, thanks Rickgordon) Pours hazy reddish orange. Raspberry aroma with some woody tones. A lot of acid notes as well. Some rubber and diesel. Fruity undertones. Full, full acid sour flavour with notes of raspberries, other berries and wood. Fruity, tart and dry. Medium body. Rerate (bottle from 2003): Pours  amber with a white head. Aroma: Still a lot of raspberries, horseblanket/barnyard, cheese, phenols and crackers. Juicy and deep. Flavour: dry, heavily bitter, citrus, horse blanket/barnyard and crackers. Mouthfeel:gastric acid,tart, medium carbonated. Lingering, citric aftertaste. Light to medium bodied.

Tap at Spuyten Duyvil.  Deep cloudy redding amber beer.  Classic Cantillon aroma, some strong tartness, huge raspberry aroma with lots of seedy woodiness coming through in the aroma.  Fresh raspberry sweetness over a light citric acidity and strong horsey/funkiness.  As it warms a bit the acidity seems to intensify highlighting the refreshing character of this brew.  Black pepper and light spiciness throughout.  Awesome stuff.

2003 Tap at Spuyten Duyvil.  Poured a muddy reddish-brown.  Big time aroma of raspberries and tartness.  Raspberries come through strongly in the flavor, along with some puckering.  Theres plenty of funkiness to go along as well.  As much as Im still getting used to lambic/sour funk, I think it works quite well with the raspberries here.  The fruity tartness lingers quite a while afterward, which is really nice.  Just great stuff.

2003 Tap at Spuyten Duyvil (june 2007). Super tart aroma loaded with fresh raspberries, soup apple, funk. Powerfully funky, a little rough around the edges. Fruit acidity comes through strongly, but still has little sweetness. Quite similar to Rose de Gambrinus, which is no surprise as they are mostly the same beer. Surprising in its deep and vigorous sourness, especially compared to the rather mellow Lou Pepe Kriek.

Bottled. Thx rickgordon.
Hazy orange/red.
Really acidic with fine, sweet fruitiness from raspberries.
Sour flavour with diesel, rubber and pleasant raspberries.

On tap at Sputyen. Deep reddish pink in color with a nice pink hue. Rasberry tart aroma. Rasberry oak and sweet flavor. Very tart notes. Finish is sour and dry. Very nice. Very drinkable. One of my favorite Cantillons.  Great.

Bottled. 2003 
Hazy red-orange colour. Gastric juice, laid back raspbeery and the overall sourness melts very well together in aroma. Rough sourness, with subtle raspberry tones in flavour. Very demanding/aquiring acidity with that dry wheat puckering your throat.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2009 First rating(2003 bottle, thanks rickgordon!) Shady light brown color, small pink head. Massive raspberry scent, also sweet and acidic. Very acidic taste. Long sour aftertaste. Extremely mouth puckering "bite down on a lemon" mouthfeel, no bitterness. Murky brown colour ... Slightly sweet raspberry nose ... Sweet fruit Raspberry with a tiny sour edge.

Bottle 2002 @ 16th Weekend of Spontaneous Fermentation 2007, Opstal. Unclear light amber red color with a average fair lacing mostly diminishing off-white head. Aroma is moderate raspberry / fruit, sweet / sour, vinegar, notes of wood. Initial flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and acidic, middel flavor is  moderate to heavy sweet and acidic, finish flavor is moderate to heavy acidic and light to moderate bitter with a long duration. Nice balance. Body is light to medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat to soft. ;o))

6 oz glass.  On tap @ Brouwers Cafe.  Dark, dark red color.  Smells like vinegar and skittles.  Taste is sour sour sour.  Way way way over the top with the sourness.  Almost impossible to finish more than the six ounce glass I had.  I had heartburn the rest of the night.
[2003 bottle] Beautiful red colour. Fast dissapearing, sizzling head. No carbonation. Tart raspberry and strawberry aroma. Very acidic, tart raspberry flavour with notes of iron. Typical Cantillon.

Bottle @ Cantillon. Cloudy red colour with no head and no lacing. Aroma was that of Cantillon when you steep into the building. With other notes of lovely raspberries, wood, tart, hint of grapefruit and other fresh fruit. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation and dry texture. Flavour was moderated acidic, not much sweetness. Fruity and sour finish. Again excellent chance to tast the great stuff from Cantillon. Belgium 25-05-2007

04 at Brouwers Belgian Fest. Wow....um, surprising to say the least. Bright cherry red. SOUR. Close to vinegar. Little sugar sweetness in the beginning. Enjoy it more after a few sips, just knocks you off your socks at first. Couldnt drink more than the 6oz I got.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2016 Restate, bottle at Cantillon. Magic raspberries, sour, woody notes, some wild strawberries. Wonderful!
Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm. Hazy red color, pinkish head. Quite sweet fruity aroma with sour and sourish nottes, raspberry, apple and oaky notes. Sour fruity flavor, raspberries, some wodd. Dry fruity finish.

Almost clear ruby, with a small creamy pink head. Smells quite sweet compared to other cantillons, lots of fresh raspberry, acid and compost. The flavour is a little like raspberry jam, but before long it was overcome by the funk and tartness. Its a little bit simpler than I expected, with the fruits being much more prominent that anything else by Cantillon Ive tried. A great desert beer perhaps.

Bottle from Capones.  Ruby clear pour with 1-finger pink head.  The head is talkative, stating, "Im going to make your mouth pucker, asshole!".   The aroma is huge tart raspberries coupled with  an earthy peaty note and some funkiness.  The taste was of huge raspberries, with huge tartness and earthy mid-palate notes.  The fruit remains very solid throughout, as does the tartness, but the taste buds seem to settle in after 2/3 of the bottle.  I prefer NG Red, but one cannot ignore the technical greatness of a fruit beer like this.

I had this beer on tap at Coopers Scranton, PA.  It was very costly for a draft ($15) but interesting to try.  It was a cloudy pinkish red color with almost no head at all.  The flavor was very tart and dry.  Worth trying on a rare occasion.

2004 on draft at Monks.  Very dark reddish color in a trumpet glass with almost no carboation or head.  Very sour and funky aroma.  Flavors of raspberry, barnyard, acid, citrus fruits.  Overall pretty nice, but not the most complex lambic Ive had.

Bottle. 2004.  Pours a bloody pink with a fizzy yet instantaneously disappearing pink head.  Acidic, yeasty aroma.  Taste is tart and sour, light-bodied.  Pretty sweet as well.  A nice lambic if not a bit steep.

Pours dark pink with a large whitish-pink head that diminishes very quickly (as demonstrated by the pourer...  I thought I was going to have whitish-pink head all over my floor but was quickly proved wrong.)  Smells fruity and sour with just the right amount of horseblanket.  Mmmm.  Tastes good, sour but not too much.  Good lambic, probably my favorite so far.
sour, very tart, raspberry, strawberry, cherry, and some lemon and orange flecks.  a little cobweb and dirty cheese flavor too.  very very dry mouthfeel with hints of carbonation.

Bottle (2003):  The aroma has lots of funky sourness with moderate sweet and tart raspberry and a hint of woodiness.  It pours a hazy pinkish-orange with a small white head that fades quickly to a ring.  The flavor ranks right up there with the more sour Cantillons.  Rasberry is definitely noticeable with sweet and tart notes.  Light woodiness barely sneaks thru all the sourness in the finish.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2007 Draft @ Monks.   Deep red pour with minimal white head.  Aroma of tart raspberries and other sour fruit flavors.  Taste was very sour & pretty tasty.  Nice for an after dinner drink.

Bottle 2002: Poured a red with thin white head. Sour raspberry aroma. The flavor was sour light berry with a musty dry finish. Im still trying to figure out these style lambics. Guess my palate wasnt made for them.
Bottle, 2004 vintage.  Dull red beer with a spritzy head.  The aroma is dull and sour and the flavour is very much like vinegar than raspberry.  Overall a disappointing beer.

Foggy red peach, thin white head.  Aroma is horseblanket, raspberries, with almost a black cherry sweetness.  Taste is jaw-tightning tart initial which you get used to after the first few drinks, followed by the subdued raspberries, and horseblanket.  Not complex, but very good.  Nice body on it.
Bottle; Nose of horseblanet and raspberries; slighly hazy yellowish red with a small pink head; very tart with raspberry notes and a fadingly sour finish.
Tried at the 12 Hour Belgian Beer Party in Carlsbad, CA. Possibly the best beer tasting ever, with 70 bottled and 20 draft beers.  This beer has a great red color.
Nice reddish light and bright color. Tart and sour with raspberry fruit tones. Refreshing style lambic.

750mL bottle, 2003 vintage.  Murky light red and orage color with a burst of fizzy pink head the quickly diminishes.  Lush tart raspberry aroma with an earthy mustiness and fruity acetic acid.  Musty sourness up front, gives way to deep raspberry and almondy flavors.  Lingering tartness in the finish as the fruit flavors drop and allow wet hay dried citric residue components to come forth.  Mouthfeel is light, rather dry.

On tap @ hopleaf during the Monthly Chicagoland Ratebeer Gathering.  Scribbling on the back of an Affligem coaster I note the nice red pink color with a thin pinkish white head.  Sugar cherry and raspberry aromas.  Very sweet flavors, sugar, fruit, brett, sour, and tart cherries.   Another nice cantillon.

On tap at Hop Leaf!  Poured a beautiful, ethereal hazy rose with nothing going on head-wise.  Aroma picked up raspberry-infused vinegar, deeper cellary must, and faint vinous notes.. occasional spikes of sour lemon and oak.. Great!  Tart raspberry and vinous notes carry the flow in the flavor department, lightly scorching the sides of the tongue after the initial hit, oak and vanilla accents push toward a tart, explosive raspberry finish.  Heavy tart and acidic notes on the palate, but never oppressive.  Lovely brew!

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2007 2004 vintage. Sampled on draft at Drafting room (Exton) and Capones (Norristown). Poured reddish pink, with a small pink head. sour, musty aroma, which real raspberry smell. Very sour, mouth-puckering, but very enjoyable. Long, tart raspberry finish. Awesome.

Sampled at the O-Town throwdown. Poured almost like pinkish red wine with thin white head. The aroma is big with tart berries, plan old tartness and some sourness. The flavor start off tart berry fruitiness followed by some tartness and then sour funkiness. Nice mixture.

Pours a very cloudy red, with a very light bubbly white head.  Very sour raspberry flavor.  I get a little more of the fruit in the cantillon then I do in most other of their fruit lambics.  Still the acidity are extremely overpowering of the fruit flavors like usual.  Still, thats what makes this such a great brewery.  They are consistent and excellent at what they do.
vintage 2000.  Pungent sour aroma.  Pours bright pink.  Sour flavor with strawberry, raspberry, with a dry finish.  I prefer the Lou Pepe Kriek

on tap at the maproom, pours dense pinkish red with pink head. nose is full of wonderfully sweet raspberries. flavor is really nice but sweet for cantillon, sweet raspberries that finish with a welcoming tartness to it. easy to drink and slightly creamy. carbination is really lively.  this is really fun to drink and i could probably drink a lot of it, but it just isnt as sour and complex as most cantillons ive tried.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2008 2003 bottle, Purchased for a hefty sum at OBriens and taken to go to a friends BDay Party.  The brew pours pink with a lighter pink frothy head.  The aroma has light rasberries in it.  The taste is sweet and tart and very sour.  The flavor is tart first and then the rasberry flavor kicks in.  I dont think I like this as much as the Lou Pepe Kriek, but it is certainly good and mouth puckering.
Bottle. Nicely acidic aroma. Hazy red colour, not as deep as the kriek. Nicely refreshing acidic flavour, rounded off by a hint of fruit. Cleans your mouth efficiently after a days beer drinking.

Bottle from Santa.  Thanks.  Pours out a pink color with a white head (after pouring rather quickly) but the head disappears almost instantly.  Somewhat cloudy looking and produces no lacing at all.  Smell is full of raspberries and some sweetness.  Full of oak, wood, musty, typical lambic smell.  Taste is pretty sour with some good hints of raspberry.  First sampling had the bottle way too cold.  After letting it sit about 30 minutes and coming back to it, the beer opened up quite a bit.  Good lambic, probably not worth the 25+ price tag that comes with it, but its still good.  Thanks Santa.

Tap at the HDG.  Poured into a tulip glass (the kind meant for girlie drinks with small umbrellas).  Color is rose pink, with orange and copper aspects. Aroma is extremely sour, tart, and acidic, more so than any bottle I have had.  Tickles the nostrils.  If you can keep your nose in the glass long enough there is a raspberry aroma with a sweetness that resembles wild strawberries.  Taste is a bit different, the "strawberry" sweetness is gone, replaced with just an extreme raspberry tartness.  Now it tickles the tonsils.  Leaves the signature acidic Cantillon aftertaste.The fun part was I got to take sips of this in between sips of the Southampton Imperial Stout.  I was tempted to blend.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: on tap at the belgian room, wasnt expecting to find this one on tap.  Poured into a wine glass.  Hazy light brown/amber in color.  Aroma is tons of barnyard funk and tart fruit.  The taste of this beer was incredibly complex, right off the bat alot of sour character, tart fruit, funk, earthy, with a good amount of acetic acid (vingegar) in the finish.

Tap at the Belgian Room - I stepped away from the festivities at the HDG strong ale fest, and what should I find but this gem on tap - I figured, "if any beer will wake up my palate after several hours of strong ale abuse, its this beer" - I was, of course, quite right - your pretty standard Cantillon aroma (barnyardy funk and tarttarttart fruits), but of course, for Cantillon, standard = fantastic - sourness that hits you right in the cheeks, making those salivary glands go crazy, whether you want them to or not - a fruitiness that isnt distinctly raspberry, but is very earth and tart (I taste seeds and skins, people) - Im too lazy to write more - I pretty much stopped analyzing it after two sips and just sat there saying "mmmmm" to myself - as the others around me kept talking, I slipped ever deeper into lambic-induced euphoria.

Celebration beer. 2001 bottle that I worried had gone bad because the cork was wet.. but bah. Its Cantillon. Clear orange.. typical Cantillon color with a small head and average at best lacing. Aroma is very tart with vinegar (more than any other Ive had from them), raspberries (duh), barnyard action, wood. Rich, complex, decadent. If these bottles were $8 or less Id live off this stuff.
Bottle (2003) at ØLbaren. Firey red - white head. Aroma: raspberries, sour. Taste: harsh sourass / gooseberries. This is not pleasant - > can anyone please help me -> I love it  - > Dry power !!!

Draught at Akkurat. Clear light red. One whiff and its Cantillon all over again. Typical house aroma. Not as outright bold as most other Cantillons but sooo refreshing.. I would drink this whole goddam thing straight away if I only I didnt know that would count as blasphemy in the afterlife...
Bottle, vintage 2003. Red, God dammit...Red! Sour aroma with fruit, dust and nostril spray(?). Flavour of fruit and fresh berries. Sweet n sour and a light bitterness. Light in palate.
(Bottle 75 cl) Pours a very pretty, clear red colour with no head at all. Distinct sourish, fruity nose. Light and somewhat watery. Fruity accents and a distinct tartness. 281006

Bottle - 2003. Pours a bright red color with a very small pinkish head that dissapated pretty quickly. Aroma is very sour and tart. Aroma is what you would expect for a lambic with the added fruit in there as well. Hints of raspberries along with yeast. Flavor is full of sourness from start to finish. Hints of raspberries come into play also which brings tartness to the beer as well. Leaves the mouth dry which calls for some more to be sipped. A pretty decent framboise. However not quite worth the sticker price to be visited very often.
Bottle at Horsens beerfestival. Red colour with a pink head. Aroma is sour,yeast, rasberry. Flavour is sour, yeast, raspberry,citrus.

2003 on the sticker.  Pours a cloudy mauve color with no head.  Aroma is a blend of lambic stank and fruity tartness that blends into a sharp funk.  Taste is extremely sour and tart.  Palate is thin.  A good frambroise, but I dont intend on spending this much cash ($18) on another bottle of it.

Bottled at Horsens Beerfestival. Red beer with some pink bubbles for head. Mould, raspberry, barnyard and almond-hints. Raspberry and lemony notes in the flavor. Thin, astringent body. Quite palate-cleansing. My best framboise so far. (061028)

Pours dark reddish orange with a nice sized frothy off-white / light pink head.  The aroma has lots of raspberries and lots of sourness.  Rich fruit and light vinegar combo. Crisp medium / light body with light amount of carbonation that is fairly sharp.  Taste has good amount of sourness and very tart raspberry.  Not quite as tart as most Cantillons though.  There is a light sweet hint from the raspberries - some rich fruit taste to offset the tartness of the original lambic. The finish has strictly tartness and less raspberry and a spicy aspect added in.  Excellent lambic overall.

Rainy day horse blanket aroma. OH MY GOD! Just crazy. One of the most sour beers Ive ever had. Its so crazy its hard to compare this to anything else. I like it, but I think the average person would think Im crazy.
Dark red colour without head. Very sour fruity aroma. Taste is equally sour (a bit too much for me)

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2016 Bottle. Small head with short duration. Color is red. Aroma and taste are rich raspberries, fruits, lactose acid, brett, vinegar and malt. Nice and sour. Great beer.
Original rating 10/28/2006 5/3/6/3/11 Bottle. Virtually no head. Color is red. Aroma is fresh and citric. Taste is rasperry with lots of lactose acid. Bitter finish.

Tried this at Delirium Cafe in Brussels, expecting a rich framboise. Instead, I got a sour taste and a dry mouth. The raspberry flavor is subdued and only really appears in the aftertaste.

Certainly not worth the 20 euros I paid for it. Lambics should be thick and voluminous, like Lindemans Pecheresse.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow & tupalev -- courtesy of tupalev. Pours a deep pinkish-red with a quick diminishing white head. Wonderful funky aroma of sour berries and yeast along with some other tart fruit. Flavour is sour and fruity, somewhat funky and damn tasty. Nice full body. Simply, a fantastic lambic -- thanks for sharing such a pricey gem Jeff!

Interesting story here.  This was my bottle shared with GregClow, Blankboy, and Hogtown Harry.  Ive had it since the beginning of the year, when I bought it in Buffalo.  Easily the most expensive bottle I have ever bought, I cant remember exactly, but it was easily $30 U.S.  But it also didnt have that cool little neck label around it telling you the year and what Lou Pepe it was (we realized at this tasting).  It doesnt help that all the Lou Peps have the exact same label (on this site anyway) which looked exactly like ours.  And what scared me the most is that I had already had the Kriek in San Francisco last year - I didnt want to spend $30 U.S. on a re-rate!!!  I thought I had the gueze but when we poured this, we instantly knew it was the Framboise.  So anyway, enough of that...wonderful aroma - so funky, yeasty, lots of malt, and lots of fruit - outstanding.  Pinkish red, small head - looks cool.  Wonderful taste - tons of sourness, fruit, earthiness and yeast.  So pungent, yet quenching.  Fruit lingers in the middle and end.  Fantastic!

Bottle shared with blankboy, tupalev & HogTownHarry - tupalevs bottle. Rating #1500! Hazy dark orange-pink with a small light pink head. Aroma - holy crap, thats funky! Lots of tart, acidic raspberry with hints of rubber and yeast - so good. Flavour has killer sour notes to start, tart raspberry, lingering dry notes, more sourness in the finish - yeah, its sour alright. Really fine stuff, and a great milestone beer. Thanks for sharing, Jeff!

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2006 Bottle (750ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow and tupalev, tupalevs EXPENSIVE bottle.  Murky pinkish red, small head.  God, thats a funky, burnt-rubber, yeasty sour aroma, hints of raspberry, its a real lambic, I want to weep.  Taste is sour, acidic, fruit-funk, yeast- more fruit character on warming and palate-adjustment.  Thick, syrupy body, very light carbonation, very acidic indeed - complex and wonderful.  Great beer.

Not sure how my description could possibly add anything to this beer. Pure raspberry; pure lambic goodness; a perfect beer in every possible way. Much as we aspire to the angelic order, so raspberries aspire to become one with the transcendent berry perfection that is Lou Pepe Framboise.

2003 Vintage. This beer really aged to perfection, or can it get better? The raspberry was very nicely balance between its tart and sweetness. It has mellowed in acidity and sourness and just smoothed over to complex and long lasting enjoyable brew.

2001 bottle: If you like blinding sourness, like lemon juice (w/complexity), then this is the beer for you.  Drinking this "beer" induces a reaction in me not unlike what would occur if I squeezed lime juice directly into my eyes.  Aaaaaaaugghhhh!  Nevertheless, who am I to say this mouth-puckering stuff is bad, necessarily.  It is extremely complex and has interesting aromas which I can comtemplate as I rush to get a glass of water to douse my agonized taste buds.  It has fascinating barnyard flavors about which I can fondly reminisce as I brush my teeth and tongue frantically.  Very little raspberry taste.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2015 Draught at GBBF 2006.  Red/pink hazy beer.  Great raspberry aroma.  Sweetish raspberry fruit in mouth.  Sour finish.  Very nice fruit.  Really like it.  Sticky sweet fruit and sour blend is perfect. 4.1 re rate 75cl bottle 2012 vintage Cantillon.  Hazy Cloudy reddish pink lasting pink head. Wild white pepper raspberry aroma. The fruit is tart I mean very tart. Dry. My god its dry. Parching. Water water. Incredible. So tart so Pippy.  So challenging.  Too harsh?  Yes. Not as good as the Carignan.

Beautiful in its frosted Bordeaux robe and ephemeral rosy white crown, theres no doubt youre in the presence of a majestic beer. Rich red fruits are vibrant in the nose, raspberries of course are escorted by cherries, wild strawberries and grapes. Bubble gum and brown sugar conjointly add a sweet dimension to the continually accreting complexity. A metallic resonance appears with time, followed by buttered toast, café au lait, watermelon and apple. The unpleasant odor of rubber gloves prevents me from awarding full marks to an otherwise exceptional aroma. Taking a sip, a deluge of berries first floods the tongue until appears a corrosive sourness that lasts long after the swallow. Pineapple, lemon and rubber share the denouement of this decidedly acerb lambic - even by Cantillon standards! My bottle was labeled 2001, and I would say it was already far downhill of its peak as the fruity flavors were not as apparent as in fresh Rose De Gambrinus, despite a double dose of raspberries. Nonetheless an excellent Framboise but I can only imagine what it must taste like young.

Draft. Raspberry red color with no head. Fruity (raspberry) and earthy aroma. Fruity, earthy, tart flavor. Not overly tart, but it does linger. Verty cleansing. Nice balance. Doesnt have the over-the-top acidity of most of their other beers. Drinkable, but didnt find it outstanding.

2003 bottle. This reddish lambic ale poured with a modest pink head that dissipated quickly. You can smell the raspberries and you can certainly taste them - fruity, carbonated and very tart. This is one of the better examples of a framboise.
Draft at OBriens.  Very fruit punch red.  Not a lot of head.  Very Raspberry aroma.  The raspberry was still in the flavor, but it was so tart... and so yummy.  Very Good

(Bottled, 0.75l, 2002 vintage) Hazy, orangeish red color with medium, fading and lemonadey head. Quite tart, strong and natural raspberry aroma. Sharp, slightly astringent, tart flavor of raspberries, citric acid, some yeast and wheat. Light to medium-bodied, crisp and quite refreshing palate.
