(05.13.06) On tap at Firkins, Libertyville, IL. Vintage 2001. Poured  hazy rose with small white head. No discernable carbonation. Fruity aroma. Light-to-medium bodied sour Flemish ale that starts dry with mouth puckering, intensely sour tartness, earthy, woody, funky flavors.  Some raspberry flavor detected but mostly hidden in this vinegary brew. Finished dry with sour acid aftertaste.  Very astringent and acidic fruity beer. Not for the meek

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2009 Bloody red with no head to speak of.  Aroma reminds me of the country days of my youth,  playing in the cow fields,  picking fruits in the wild, running in the barns, my first hard-on for Kim (but thats another story).  Cherries flavour/sourness is not as overwhelming as in many other beers of its kind.  Acidity and tartness are not over-the-top either.  A somewhat restrained but pleasant Fruit Lambic that while not making me a fan of the genre, made me think that it may eventually grow on me.

Draught at Red Bones 6/17/06. Pours a bright red color with a small minimal white head. Nose is brett with a touch of raspberries. Palate is sour and acidic. Flavor is mostly brett with hints of sour raspberry and a very nice sourness that doesnt compare to most cantillons though is still a force with this brew.

Post-Mondial tasting at Goldoraks pad, from 2002 750 ml bottle.  Salmon-pink colored body with a mere touch of fizzy head....raspberry-biscuit aroma with lots of elegant aged farmy touches alongside some odd fuesels (burning plastic and rubber), dry and dusky and a bit leathery.....the body is massively tart throughout, highly acidic, finishing with lots of mineral salts and just impossibly sour apples and tart berries, really powerful and as hard as any Cantillon Ive had, surprising as I thought the Lou Pepes were supposed to be sweetened? ....anyway this is a fine example, rough and tough and refined all at once, drinkable and refreshing despite the huge acidity.

"Milestone beer for me 500 enjoyed with eaglefan. Poured a cherry color with small head no lacing. Aroma was tart tart lemons and raspberries. Flavor was much the same with the typical lambic funk/cheese in there. Good beer."
Cloudy reddish colour with a small pink head. Strawberry sweet fruity aroma with notes of yeast and wood. Light tart berry fruity flavor with a yeasty and dry finish.

Thanks to turdfergusson for sharing this bottle with me.  This glass of beer was full of the addictive funk that only cantillon can produce.  The sour musty funk was balanced perfectly with the tart raspberries in this 2002 bottle.  It was extremely sour and very sweet (lambicular perfection?)  Each sip made me want to keep it in my mouth and enjoy the amazing cornucopia of flavors going on... I think we might have turned a couple of people onto lambics with this bottle... this was an amazing beer experience.

Vintage 2003. Enjoyed this milestone 1000 beer w/ bfeldman, who was hitting 500 at the same time (woo hoo!). Poured a very pretty cherry red color with a nice initial head, but no lacing. The aroma was of tart lemons, some raspberry. Flavor was all of that and some light cheese, leather, barnyard funk, all that stuff. Mouthfeel was acidic, nice tart punch. Nice stuff. Wow, 1000 beer reviews, a nice night cap too!
Post-mondial Tasting. Couleur rouge/orange avec petit collet. Arome fruit sûre intéressant. Goût très sûre, mais je me suis habitué.

Neat ruby colour, small fine top. Sweet and sour raspberry aroma. Very refreshing, true fruity spirit. Tart, sour fruity front that got milder with finish. Drinkable with lovely tart fruity character.
Pours red with no real head.  Smells of balsamic vinegar, raspberries and barnyards.  Taste is over the top sour and tarte with some nice sugary raspberry qualities.

Bottle.
Hazy red coloured with a light pink head.
Aroma of berries and wood with light acidic notes.
Acidic flavour of berries with notes of wood.
UPDATED: OCT 30, 2006 bottle. beautiful red color. lots of carb. very dry. sour vinegar taste. distinct fruit smell and taste.
Bottle. Reddish in colour with a small head. A bit sour with nice fruityness. Nice dryness and a hint of vinegar.

(Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm 30 April)  Vintage 2003 - Unclear dark red, very small white head; medium sized, very deep nose with lots of complexity: in one way it has fresh raspberry and raw sugar, in another it has very distinctive gueuze notes: horse, cow barn and some citrus; the body is super fresh with loads of acidity and sourness, it has very little fill. I think all the sourness that makes the body fill a bit thin and overshadows some of the complexity; very long very sour finish that builds up very well with a very harsh tannin that makes the beer chewy: initially loads of framboizen, later grapefruit, citrus and wood.

Magenta color, with a light pink head that quickly diminishes. Raspberries, hay, and barnyard funk come through in the aroma. Flavor is of raspberries, as expected, and the tartness is somewhat restrained. Earthy barnyard notes come through in the finish.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2009 (Vintage 2003. Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm 30 Apr) Colour is clear red, with little head. Nose is acidic, harsh with some raspberry character. Taste is acidic and harsh with some raspberry character evident. Very dry and acidic finish. A very nice beer, but the acidity overshadows the berry character a bit too much. Ɩ/4/6/4/15=3.5) Rerate: draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, 22 Sep 2009. Dark red colour with frothy, pink head. Tart, acidic nose with red berries, raspberries, stable, barnyard and a touch of wood. Tart taste with notes of red berries, raspberries, wood and a dry, tart, harsh finish. The same taste elements as in the first rating, but a lot more fresh and tasty. Lovely beer.
Pink/orange body.  Pinkish thin head.  Nose is raspberry, barnyard cantillon funk, oak, cherry pits.  Flavor is tart raspberry, cherry, lemon.  Cantillon funk finish w. just a hint of fruit.

Batch made specially for the 2006 festival of Leuven Beer Therapeutists. Old lambic, fresh raspberries, sugared liqueur for refermentation. Draught. Very dark orange with a fine veil of fruit pulp particles; no head. Pure fruit aroma with traces of lambic behind. Fruity, sourish taste with a remarkable aftertaste bitterness from the fruit stones. Light oily and prickling sensation on the tongue.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2008 From bottle, poured at the 2006 Pizza Port 12 Hour Belgian Beer Party.  Brilliant sunset red pour with a flamboyantly pink head.  Vinegary aroma with a fruity dimension of sour cherries and raspberry marmalade along with an earthy dimension of hay and lemon bark.  Overly acidic flavors crowd my palate and disguise some of the organic fruit aspects that are so enjoyable in the bouquet.  Finish is long, but excessively dry.  8-4-7-3-15=3.7  On tap at OBriens, 2003 Vintage.  Pours an incredibly deep raspberry red color with some pink hues and a quickly diminishing champagne head.  Wonderfully tart aromas of raspberry and strawberry.  Plenty of musty earth herbal tones - raspberry seeds, stems, leaves, and roots give this a nice, earthy floral spice.  Light bodied, crisply acidic mouthfeel with a pleasant champagne effervescence.  Very sour, amazingly pleasing flavors of fruit, fruit, and more sour fruit.  A long finish brings out the dry characters of the beer.  8-4-9-4-16=4.2

From a 750mL Bottle, 2003 Vintage.  Somewhat hazy, ruddy pink colored pour with a quickly dissipating head of pale pink.  Juicy raspberry fruit aromas with hints of seeds, but lots of jammy sweetness.  Light herbal bitterness and musty, leathery funk.  Light bodied, sparkling mouthfeel with a bold acidity.  Acidic, fruity raspberry flavors up front, but the lemony gueuze-like flavors quickly replace the fruitiness.  Theres almost an ammonia like sourness in the finish, and it hides the fruits a bit too much without really providing any additional sour complexities, making it taste a bit muddled overall.  I certainly like the freshness and fruity tartness of the latest vintage Rose bottles substantially more than the raspberry flavors in this particular bottle.  8-4-7-3-15=3.7
Rating is a composite of past tastings.

2002 vintage cloudy reddish colour with almost no foam; robust aroma of raspberries (what a pleasure to smell real fruits in comparison to the chemical experiences offered by too many breweries nowadays !); notes of hay, chesse and vinegar; medium-bodied, low carbonation; strong beautiful and complex acidity; the finish is long, dry and very acidic with more notes of raspberries and hay - what a great lambic !

Bottled in 2001. Hazy, dull red with a creamy white head. Sour aroma with some wet hay and raspberries. Very tart in flavor with some horse blanket retronasal qualities and a bit of raspberry. Finishes very dry. Unfortunately, I didnt take notes when this was cracked at 5am this morning after a crazy night, so my memory is not perfect. Must try again....

(750ml bottle, 2001 vintage)  Pours a clear ruby body with a small white head.  The nose exhibits mustiness, earthiness, sweat, and sour fruit characteristics.  The age has nicely balanced the acidity and sourness with a dry, organically distinctive finish.
2003. Red colour with a small pinkish head. Nice fruity raspberry aroma. Flavor is sour raspberry leaving you with a nice and long fruity aftertaste. Very nice.

2001:  Pour was hazy pinkish red with a small red head...smell is exactly as I thought it would be...tart sour raspberry...taste was very strongly sour and funky with lots of raspberry tartness, but no real sweetness...
A pretty near perfect drinking (to type) experience. 2003. Just a pleasure to let the raspberry pour over your tongue. A nice cranberry color. A tart finish that leaves your crying for more.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2012 Tap, Maxs 72 hours. 2003. Light rose body with no head. Light raspberry aroma, barnyard funk, lacto-sourness. The flavor is immediately sour and slightly sweet with a nice compliment of raspberries, before finishing sour and dry, apples and lemons. The raspberries are just part of the equation here, you still can taste the Lambic, unlike Lindemans. The mouthfeel is light with soft carbonation.  2001, feb 2011. Amazing fruity nose, tons of seedy raspberries, light acetic acid. Taste is very sour, lots of acetic acid, lots of fruit. Very good, but brutish, just too sour.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2007 2003 vintage on tap at The Moan and Dove. (also have sampled several 2002 750s) the color alone turns me on, a very deep pink witth a small fizzy white head. this stuff looks amazing. aromas of funk, sour raspberries, funk, and more funk.  gotta have that funk!  This stuff is great. Tangy and tart throughout and I really cant get enough of it. One of the best lambics ive had so far. yummy.

A Mes rate: 
75cl bottle from Cantillon. Another one that we had to promise the very good people at Cantillon that we would stash until it was ready. Not quite so worth the wait as the Kriek but still mighty fine stuff. Aroma although decent is a little too funky for me to be truthful. Appearance is a slightly hazy wonderful blood red colour. Flavour is very sour with all the usual lambic characteristics and just a polite nod to the raspberries. Dry and tangy without the lick of sweetness at the finish that the Kriek had. In fact the finish is almost lemony. Not one for anyone who doesnt fully appreciate lambics but for someone who does you will know that this could be better. Very good beer but not Cantillons best.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2008 20051012  2001, 750ml bottle at RLB YEHA-05  Murky, dark pink with fizzy pink head.  Aroma had hints of berry, sure there was some nice brett and spicy yeast, and mint - in fact, I noted a distinct aroma of urinal cake.  Im not saying it was bad, thats just what I smelled.  Flavor is much more focused on berries and beer.  Dry and rather harsh, sharp eff, sharp acidity.  Really reminds of breakfast cereal with those dehydrated berries.  I liked it, but it was the kookiest beer of the night for me.  2003 at Spuyten Beast of the Yeast.  Wow, massive raspberry nose.  Hugely tart.  So much berry, this winner is all about doing fruit right.  Up from 7-5-7-4-15

2001 bottle, the third Lou Pepe of the trifecta for me!  surprisingly goldish yellowy color.  light pinkish white head.  tart and sour unripe raspberry aroma.  tart and sour flavor but less raspberry/much fainter than I was expecting.  makes sense though that the fruit flavor fades over time.

2002 vintage, sampled at the Yeha.  Poured a cloudy pale red.  Sour raspberry aroma.  Taste is very sour with good raspberry flavor, much more fruit presence than other Cantillons Ive had.  Forms phlegm in the back of the throat.

Draught @ DBA in New York City.  Deep cranberry red color, with a lightish pink head.  Extremely rich, authentic and elegant raspberry aroma, with an apple core aroma underneath.  Upon tasting, it had a very unpleasant and distracting apple like lambic character in the blend, which to me, showed more applely lambic flavor, than raspberry fruit.  Im a lambic beginner, but it just seemed well, not very complex.  Just like the Lou Pepe Kriek, I wish an older blend was used (rather than just two year), yielding more tartness, but my biggest complaint is the flavor of the lambic blend, not the fruit.

2001 vintage. Pours a cloudy red color with a ring of offwhite lace. Excellent aroma of sour raspberries and cheese. Excellent flavor of raspberries and cheese with strong and dominant acidity. The body is light with a dry, dusty and cobwebby mouthfeel. Excellent lambic, the best from the Lou Pepes. Thanks Rich !
UPDATED: FEB 8, 2006 Very strong, but sweet at the same time, I liked it very good. But it was getting me too drunk. NIce colour. 2002.
UPDATED: MAY 22, 2006 [bottle from beers of europe] Pink with a fluffy pink head. This is extremely smelly, raspberrys, wet horsey, cheesey, sweaty lambic goodness. light bodied, sour finish.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2008 I think im just not hardcore enough for this type of stuff yet, but anyway. Aroma is hardcore feety, soggy cardboard, funky lambic yeast, no rasberry yet. Taste is similar with a hardcore sour lemon funkiness domination, with a sweetish finish. Hardcore stuff, and well i thought i was hardcore but obviously not hardcore enough. RERATE: Same score, i think this is the weakest of the cantillon line up havaing had it a few times now. Still good enough to have a bottle of now and then.

2001 vintage, just like the picture.
Brownish and quite murky, like most Cantillons the head was lively at first but died off rapidly.
Crush some sour, unripe raspberries, stick that jam into a well used baseball glove and leave it between two bales of hay during a rainy October and thats what this Beer smells like.  I kid you not.
A bit more fruity than a kriek, but the difference is almost negligible.  The acidity beats up your tongue and bullies your taste buds for its lunch money.  Like the Parliament Funkadelic is jamming in my mouth!

2001 vintage
I realize people expect this beer to be venerated as a matter of axiom simply because it is one of the best examples of a narrowly appreciated style. The thinking goes, "if you dont like sour lambics, dont rate them." Sorry, I just cant play along with that game any more than I would give a high rating to a certain brand of  ketchup stout or a turnip wheat simply because it was the best known example of the style. A $28 bottle of beer had better taste like liquid orgasm. Instead it tasted like raspberry vinegar. You are welcome of course to take my review with a grain of salt, but Im not going to celebrate a beer I find undrinkable just because its a prime example of an almost undrinkable beer style (though there a few  sour ales I find quite enjoyable). I tried to give Cantillon one more chance. Never again. All you super-sour lambic fans are welcome to this stuff.

Bottled. 2000 vintage. Pours a nice brownish red colour with a tiny, diminishing head. Aroma is raspberryish with a barnyard undertone and some citric and corky notes. Very acidic and quite tart. Oak, raspberries, hay. The acidity made it hard to consume the whole bottle, as it burned it my throat and stomach. But apart from that, a wonderfully tart and fruity beer, which seems to have aged well. Huge thanks to bierkoning for providing me with this vintage.
Dark reddish appearance. No head. Raspberries are dominent in all aspects in this beer. Quite sour finish. Truly a nice refreshing brew.

750ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Bright red/pink. Fizzy dissipating pink head. Aroma of lemon, brett, barnyard, cheese and citric raspberry. Also a hint of cherry. Excellent lip pursing lemon sourness in the taste. Good long acidic finish.

2002 bottle: Cloudy luminescent red with a pink small head. Big sour funky aroma. Lots of rotting raspberrys. Sour intense flavour, loads of sweet raspberrys with a juicy acidic finish. Very refreshing, and wonderfully complex.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2005 Vintage 2001:  This is another one of those lambics where I have to admit, "I dont get it."  Ive grown to enjoy the Limburger qualities of a good gueuze, but I dont enjoy it when applied to fruit.  Its just not fun to me when the stale fruit aroma is "enhanced by that of sweaty gym socks.  Sour and barnyard-ish, the fruit flavors come across as if theyve already been eaten.  Still, I will try this and re-rate it in the future as I try to broaden and develop my tastes.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eve Fest at Delilahs, Chicago, IL 06/04/2005<font size=-1>

there is nothing better then an expensive beer bought by some one else.  bottle from 2001.  Beer smells slightly sour and fruity and sweet.  It pours blood red which is pretty interesting if your used to regular beer. Flavor wise this a great beer.  Its sour, but not too sour, its fruity, but not to fruity.  Its very balanced.  I cant really say that there is any real problem with this beer.  If you got the money give it a try.

Bottle from Beers of Europe.  Red/pink in colour with no head after a short wait.  Aromas are raspberry and vanilla with cheese, stinky feet and that Cantillon farmyard effect.  Flavours are sour raspberry with soft cheese.  Citrus acidicy jabbers your jowls.  This is another good Cantillon.  I have had all the Lou Pepe lambics now and this is as good as the others.

2002 vintage, bottled 2004. Intensely deep pink-red colour, hazy and hardly any carbonation so it barely poured with any head and that didnt last long at all. Amazingly strong raspberry aroma - wow! The fruit character really makes this beer - theres just loads of raspberry jam and a fair bit of seed character. Yum! Otherwise the aroma is the typical Cantillon character with the emphasis on sweat and dried fish. Theres also a fair bit of raspberry character in the flavour and an intense lactic sourness but I think Im coming to realise that a lot of Cantillons stuff doesnt really have much else. Whereas the 750mL bottle of Oud Beersel Gueuze went like a flash, it became a bit of a chore to get through the entire bottle of this, as there really isnt that much besides the fruit character and the searing acidity. Its still a very, very good beer, its just not mindblowing. I think if Id had a 200mL glass of this it would have gained a much higher rating.

Bottle, from the brewery. 2002 season. Cherry pink, no head and minimal condition. Raspberry tartness and gentle leathery notes in the nose, quite earthy in the mouth with a pleasant soft raspberry tartness. Long bone dry lambic finish with some bitter raspberry fruitiness lingering.
UPDATED: MAY 9, 2007    Beautiful beer to look at smell and taste. Extreme complexity and depth wonderful sour fruit nose and signature cantillon backbone.

Brilliant bright clear ruby, huge pink head that loudly and rapidly pops away to nothing.  Smells like a Cantillon, which is to say its hugely sour and funky, cheesy, and musty.  Faint whiff of raspberries, but not much fruit in nose.  Initial taste is a massive burst of sour and fruit, face-clenchingly puckering.  Cheesy, dusy, and musty, barnyard skunk, powerfully sour.  Rasberries are slight, more in the finish.

Good stuff.. although at a heafty price. 2001 750ml bottle. Deep red/purple color with a very faint head. Aroma is tart with a rasberry permiation. Flavor is also tart with an initial pop of acidity followed by the rasberry. Dry and very user friendly. I would recommend this to anyone willing to spend that kind of money.

From a 2001 vintage 750ml bottle. Very dark red body. Beautiful coloring. The head is a thin off white. Lively carbonation. The aroma is massive raspberries. Also hints of vanilla, must and wodo in the background. Not nearly as funky of an aroma as I had expected. Taste is mouth puckering and in your face. It has hints of leather and wood with a salty finish. The mouthfeel is sticky. The raspberries are barely tasted, but definitely in the aftertaste. A nice dry finish on the palate. Balsomaic vinegar notes are definitely here. As Joeh noted, the raspberries become more apparent as you drink more. While this is very sour, it is also complex and enjoyable. A very nice example of the style.

750ml corked and capped bottle bought from Cantillon in Brussels. Poured into a straight Cantillon glass. Dark red-purple, hazy and almost completely still with no head. Aroma is vinious with sharp raspberry jam aroma and background acidity. Theres something else there in the aroma also, a sort of a vinegarish meaty character. Flavour is similar - sour and tart with some sharp fruitiness. The raspberry character is overwhelmed through sharpness at first, but later raspberry seed/pip flavours come in. Has a fair bit of body and thickness to it, surprisingly. Nice stuff.

Aroma is sour, sweet and true raspberry. Hazy pinkish/red, with the tiniest of pink fringe, near the bottom of the glass lie raspberry seeds. Flavours are very pronounced, with raspberries, some sourness, tartness, earthiness, barnyard, wet blanket, the whole range.(pardon the pun) Complex, medium bodied, tart, sweet, dry as can be. Fantastic!
 ThankYou NorthYorkSammy!

2001 Vintage. Cloudy red-amber w/ lots of sediment & a delicate, frothy pink head. Fresh, tart raspberry aroma w/ notes of leather, horse blankets(?), sharp cheese, iron, & oak. Light, highly carbonated feel w/ some raspberry grittiness. Complex, tart raspberry flavour w/ an underlying sweetness & notes of oak, iron, & cheese. Dry finish.

Cloudy beautiful pink, with real raspberries. Cider-like aroma and no barnyard. Great sediment of more sour at bottom of bottle. Very smooth drink, hard to gulp down although I gave it a college effort. 2001 vintage. Must be shared. Seems richer than 5%.
Bottle from Cantillon Brewery (2004 edition). Rich, deep syrup. Smooth, thick, powerful. Controlled sourness and a blended fruit hit. No carbonation or head. Luminous pink. Very strong Lambic Fruit.

Beautiful pristine ruby hue accented by frosty bubbles. Vision the most perfect raspberry covered in straw and dusted with yeast.  Initial spritzy mouthfeel softens into soft berries with oak backdrop.

2003 bottling: Brilliant scarlet with a slight chill haze. Tall and milky, light rose collar of foam. Intense nose of rust, flowers, sulfur, and stinky brett. Fresh essence of mashed raspberries with dried leather and overripe peach pit hints. Feathery fluff to the carbonation. Slightly gritty texture. Exquisite raspberry flavor immediately arrives to balance the bustling tartness. Intensely dry, throughout, with a firm musty oak stamp soon grabbing foothold, deepening the tartness and adding more flavor depth. Understated, but masterfully utilized zippy brett character, couples with an herbal yeast flare which lends more dryness. Slowly developing scratchy mineral texture is curbed by a filmy maraschino cherry-like softness. Subtle notes of leather and medicine. Continual irony, dried apricot acidity bolsters the juiciness and lengthens the remarkably bright raspberry notes. Ends persistently juicy, yet briskly dry and acidic, with a shockingly harmonious interplay of brett, oak, and the vaguest touch of Pilsner malt that lingers long past its departure. The eptiome of balanced complexity. One of the most elegant beers in the world.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 18, 2005 Copenhagen beer marathon 2004. 2002 edition, Red color, Sweet light acid raspberry aroma, medium sour dry taste, full body, dry finish.

I believe this was a 2001 edition, sampled at the Belgian Beerfest. Brilliant bright red with no head. Sharp acidic and citric aroma, low raspberry profile. Sharp sourness, the raspberries take a back seat to the gueuze here, creating a more refined sourness. If anything, a bit one-dimensional. Absolutely dry finish. Oh glorious Lou Pepe, if only you didnt cost $30 bottle...

2002 Edition Bottle.  Raspberry sour musty farmhouse aroma.  Hazy fire engine red color with minimal head.  Sour to start, but not overwhelming like the Rose de Gambrius.  Sweet raspberry flavors come through in the finish.  A much better experience with Cantillon than my first...

bottle. bright ruby color... lip smacking... playfully puckering... sour rasberries... a great lambic... light, fun, makes me wanna say "weeeeee!!!"... but this could be because this was one of the last brews i had at the fest
Sweetish raspberry nose, nice sourness. Light reddish body, small head. Very sour flavor, but nice sweetness from the fruits.

Bottle at Copenhagen Beermarathon 2004: Pours Deep red. Aroma is intense rasberries, very slightly malty, and a generous amount of the farmyard smell from the brettanomyces. Taste is sour, acidic, dominated by rasberries. As with all the other Cantillons ive had, is this a very good lambic

2001 Vintage:Pinkish orange color with a lightly pinkish beige head. Strong sour gueuze-like aroma with lemon, raspberry and wood. Very nice  sour flavor with lemon, sour raspberry, hay and vinegar. Very dry with tiny, spritzy bubbles and a very dry finish. Very enjoyable!

2001 Vintage: Very pretty cranberry color with a pinkish/beige head. The aroma was very gueuze-like...lemon zest, hay, sour raspberry, wet fur, and old wood. The flavor was quite sour...raspberries, lemon, hay, vinegar. The feel was super spritzy...extremely dry finish. Nice.

01 vintage: Large light pink head that drops out quickly. Lightly hazy berry color. Good raspberry nose, lightly sour, vinegary notes, musty. Medium body, medium acidity. Pucker up baby! Nice sourness, tart raspberry flavor, fruity, lightly musty along with some hoseblanket/ barnyard notes, all that goooood stuff. Yeast and some citric notes showing up as it starts to warm, nice. Dry, tart finish. A nice Framboise. Thanks to slikwily for the chance at rating this one! Thanks bro!

Very impressed with this one.  Ruby red body with a frothy light pink head.  Rasberry, barn, and cobweb nose.  Tartness was definitly there but not at all abrasive.  Fresh from the vine rasberry flavor and acidity blended perfectly with earth, stale hops, and a touch of barnyard.  Finished nice and clean.  Captured essence of rasberry.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2006 On draught at Redbones in Somerville, MA.  You can imagine my huge surprise and delight at seeing a beer as rare as this on draught.  I assume its a 2002 bottling (kegging), but thats just an assumption, not really sure.

Pours a bright neon red, cloudy with no head.  Incredibly bright and a wonderful color, with obvious sediment mixed throughout.  Aroma has fresh, sweet raspberry, light fructose sugars, and hints of moderately tart leathery tannins.  A real bittersweet tartness.

Flavor is simply spectacular.  Surprisingly, this one isnt that all around tart (for Cantillon).  The raspberries dont taste musty or meaty, just quite sweet, ripe and fresh.  They mix in nicely with the light yeast notes, and tartness.  There is a winey/leathery acidic note throughout but it is coupled with a lovely, hefty wheat body and just sits on the palate and lingers on.  Finish is a bit thin, perhaps from being on draught so far from home, but that was the only complaint.  Smooth, lightly spritzy and medium-full bodied (loosening on the finish).  Great stuff and I will be going back for more very soon.

On tap.  Color is a deep red with no head.  Aroma is of raspberries.  Taste is nicely sour with raspberry/citrus finish.  Pretty dry.  I dont know how to rate lambics.  Its so different from other beers that its hard to compare.  As lambics go I like it, but I wouldnt want a full pint of it.

3/13/04.  Poured out of 750 mL bottle, sampled at Pizza Port 12-Hour Belgian Festival '04 in Carlsbad, CA 3/13/04.  2001 Vintage.  Pours a hazy ruby red with not much head that lingers in a thin ring along the edges.  Lacing is patchy and very fast.  Not great.  Strong raspberry aroma, tart and dry and slightly grassy.  Flavor is a bit acidic, tart and astringent.  Dry raspberries.  Extremely complex, it continues to unfold in the mouth with each new sip.  Absolutely delicious.  Easily the best of the three different Lou Pepe styles Ive had the pleasure to try.
soft reddish color, head is pinkish, thick, mostly diminishing. aroma is very fruity, hot tar, pretty damn funky. flavor is amazingly tart, fruity....awesome lambic.

Reddish/amber color with a very small
pink head. Sweet raspberry aroma with
a hint of mustiness and earth. Beautiful
tart raspberry flavor that is incredibly refreshing. A great lambic along with the
Lou Pepe Kriek.
Vintage 2001Cloudy red color. Very nice, biting, fruity aroma (pungent). Absolutely sour, fruity, real raspberries. Excellent! Thanks Joris for sharing this bottle.

This brew pours with a ruby red body topped by a thin head with little lacing.  The aroma is slightly sweet yet sour and full of raspberry with a touch of barnyard.  The flavor is tart, sour and a touch sweet with barnyard notes and a touch of raspberry.  Light bodied, crisp and dry.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2005 Pours a briht cloudy reddish/orange with almost no head... Aromas of yeast and that good old barnyard odor.  Flavor is tart and sour and te flavor of strawberies isnt overpowering..  Would go well with fish.

WCCII: Cloudy light red-brownish with a small head. Light strawberry aroma. Amazingly enough, the taste is of strawberry is rather weak. Even for a Cantillon I found this beer a bit too acidic. Still, it is a good product.

Bottle-2001 Vintage, shared with Chris_O. This was my fave beer at the catford beer fest. and props to Chris_O for chipping in some cash to share a bottle of this baby. As always with Cantillon, huge bone-dry sourness, rasberry seeds, as always, theres the barnyard funk, so sour and tart, could have kept drinking it for a while actually (or maybe i was just drunk?), my stomach didnt feel so good the next morning though.

Ruby pour with a light pink, frothy head. Sweet and funky aromas of barnyard. This is what I want from a lambic. Sour, tart and dry. Vinous, earthy and some hints of tobacco. Yes! Flavors are tart and dry with dusty cobwebs. Barnyard funk and vinous. Some tobacco. I love it. Dry palate, puckers the mouth.  Same with the finish.

Deap mahogany pour with bright red highlights. Thick foamy soapy head with a slight redish tint. Woody raspberry smell. Fruity citrus smell came to the nose. Beautiful sticky lacing. Very strong sour tart taste. Makes the tastebuds jump! Very sour, tart, like vitamin C. Very delicious, makes my mouth water and water and water. Makes the mouth pucker from the musky tartness. Thanks Bück Dich...Happy Birthday!

Ruby amber/mahogany creamy sticky head & lacing. The aroma is a buschel of raspberries & tons of barny tart complexity. The taste is full of tart gueuziness & barny tart yummy. Dry & musky like Jean-Pierr intends with a noted lack of residual sweetness, lite sulfer in the tail. Thanks Slikwily!

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2004 750ml bottle, vintage 2001, at Monks in Philly. Pours red, with a pink head. Aroma is raspberries, and the taste is of sour raspberries. Body is on the thin side. It doesnt really taste like beer, more like a raspberry cider. Glad I was able to try it.

750ml bottle at Catford Beer Festival (33rd beer of the day including one accdental duplicate). After getting all the beers I need,  plus a strong cider, plus a strong perry and drinking for 9 hours with (at various times) SilkTork, Spiesy and Duff (only Duff and I left by this time), it was probably time for home.  However, that foreign beer bar on the way out did look terribly tempting. And Duff almost went apoplectic when he saw this was available. Go on then, even if it did mean a whole 750ml bottle between the two of us. Duff went into raptures and Ill let him do the superlatives once hes written up his thousand or so outstanding rates. Not to mention my crtical faculties being pretty numbed by this time. Ill limit myself to saying that this was excellent stuff, but I cant help preferring the "straight" lambics and gueuzes to the fruit ones. Consequently it comes below the Cantillon gueuze in my pecking order.
SLightly sweet raspberry aroma.  Big sour raspberry flavor carries to the finish.  Finishes to the dry side.

Bottled: Red unclear coloured. Has a large reddish head, that disappear in a milisecond. Quite odd. Extremely delicious aroma of rasberrries, sourness, fruitsweetness, wood and earthnotes. Yummy. Flavour is initially very sour and refreshing. Changes into a more citrusy and grapish note. Raspberry flavours is there in the background. Has a nice sweet/sour aftertaste with a long lasting. Good one.

[Vintage 2001] A hazy raspberry red beer with an extremely pink fast disappearing head. The aroma is fantastic of raspberries, wood, and sourness from the wild fermentation. The flavor is sligtly sour, that runs along the side of the tongue, but the real sourness dies quite fast and becomes like grapefruit. The end is somewhat woody. The mouthfeel is a little thin, which is surprisingly for a Cantillon. Thanks to MadsBerg for bringing this to a tastingsession.

Vintage 2001.Pours a frothy though fast disappearing pink head on a deep pink body. Aroma is tart and sour with strong tones of wood and grapefruit and some sweet berries underneath. Flavor is very acidid with strong wood notes and also grapefruit and raspberry. Dry. A typical Cantillon lambic, very extreme, but not as good as the Lou Pepe Kriek, the raspeberries are not evident enough. Huge thanks to madsberg for sharing this!
[2001 vintage] Deep red coloured. Great natural aroma of raspberries. Sourness, tartness and the fruit is very well balanced.

2004 Mondial de la Biere Ratebeer Gathering at Tiggmtls. Red colour with a thin white head. Light raspberry hovers over a ton of barnyard, musty and yeasty aroma, plus both lactic and acetic acidity. Starts with a pleasant mix of berry and acidic sourness, building to a lemony, acetic, and slightly cheesy finish. Very dry but quite refreshing. Much appreciated MartinT.

When am I going to learn?  I keep buying this style and hoping to find some good ones but am usually disappointed.  And out quite a few bucks.  This poured a cloudy burgundy with a fast disappearing pink head.  The nose was of tart raspberry and wasnt too bad.  The flavor, however, was just awful.  Extremely tart.  Unpleasant.  I truly wanted to like this stuff but couldnt.  Tasted with several members of the beer club and no one liked it.

Cloudy dark red color, almost no head, only some lacing. Aroma is more fruity of real raspberry, some cork. Slightly tart taste, which is nicely balanced with fruity and sweeter tastes. Bit sticky mouthfeel.

Barnyard and sour raspberries in the aroma. Deep opaque red, minor head, looks still but carbonation is good. Mildly acetic raspberries, gooseberries and red currants. Straight up fruit lambic. Mouthfeel is fairly still but with a sweet languor about it. Very enjoyable if somewhat simple. Bottle (marked 2001 - sampled at Mondial RB Gathering 2004 with CapFlu, CaptainCougar, jercraigs, MartinT, OKBeer, Radek and Rastacouere).

dutch ratebeer lambic-meeting. Cloudy, red coloured with a short pink head. Aroma of real raspberries and tartness. Taste is of raspberries, tartness and oak. No heavy sweetness. Well balanced. Dry palate.

Real raspberry aroma, tart and some vinegar. Pinkish red color, very small pink head that disappears quickly leaving no lace. Immediatly sour start, very fruity, light raspberry, vinegar, light bitterness, oak, dry. Certainly not a sessionbeer.

Dutch ratebeer lambic-meeting: Bottle says 2001 vintage, cork says bottled in 2003. Cloudy dark red coloured, rapidly disappearing head. Strong sour flavour with some vinegar. Not being a big fan of raspberries in beer i somehow found this to be quite ok.

Pours a pretty red clear color with a big head that is almost fully diminishing.  Aroma is beautifully sour that kind of burns your nose hairs.  Raspberry notes evident.  Flavor is sour raspberry with an excellent citrus acidity.  Body is semi-dry and short.  This is really good stuff.

(Bottle) Post Mondial Gathering 2004 at TiggMTL. Fruit punch colour. Great sour notes of raspberry. Dry - err... very very dry. Very good flavour of raspberry and so dry I need to drink more. Many thanks to MartinT for this offering...

Hazy bright ruby read colour with a pinkish white head. Powerfully sour tart lambicy aroma. Mouthfeel is puckering but quite refreshing. The tart raspberry flavours sneak in quite subtley but are just enough to reign in the tart acidity that dominates the flavour. Very well balanced and drinkable which says a lot coming from the guy who couldnt even finish the regular Cantillon Lambic.  Very nice. Many thanks to MartinT.

Bloody light red, very thin pink head. Aroma is extremely barnyardy, like when you pick raspberries in a field where cows have passed and left their "trace". Lactic sour yogurt past its prime, mild cask wood. Very fruity acidic palate, citric, lactic with definite blood oranges flavors. I think Id like it better if it was more sour. Cask wood flavors, while there, seems also a bit restrained to me. Medium carbonation, medium bodied. Those beers are great, no doubt about it, but I guess its the oak and fruit focus that makes the difference between a great beer and an exceptional one. Lou pepe framboise, while very complex and apparently well blended doesnt strike to me as the perfect blend of complexity and focus. I had greatly anticipated this beer for a long time and stand disappointed though, its fairly similar to the lou pepe kriek and while being authentic and a quality product, just doesnt appear to me even as a top shelf framboise and how many of those are there? Thanks Martin!

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2011 (2010 on the cork 2008 on the top label):Beautiful equilibrium of fresh raspberries, lambic funk, lemony acidity and authenticity. Superb job from Cantillon; complex and elegant, never over-the-top and simply funky.

(2003 on the cork, 2001 on the top label): Compassionate lemony acidity leaves a little room to some scared raspberries...As balanced as the other Lou Pepes, with perfect levels of tartness for refreshment, but this one remains quite simple and light-bodied...This is nowhere near the Drie Fonteinen Framboos in fruitiness, blend quality and organization of sourness/otherworldliness...A clean, straightforward and funkless summer aperitif...3.7/5

(2005 on the cork; 2001 on the label):Just more of everything, which is incredible because thats what was lacking in the earlier vintages...Super acid, super funky, tons of raspberries everywhere...A vintage to respect...4.3/5

Red in colour with a pink head. Nose is sour and acidic with a hint of raspberries. Flavour is sour with good raspberry flavour and well carbonated. As far as enjoyment is concerned, its a step below Lindemans and not even comperable to New Glarus.

2001 bottle. Very lively pink head that collpases in a riot of bubbles. Pink-red body that is very appealing. The aroma almost knocks you off your feet, sour raspberry and some barnyard. The flavor is quite spectactular, sour raspberry, barnyard, minimal sweetness, and maybe some woodiness. Very typical of Cantillon and very good.

2001 Bottle thanks to CaptainCougar. Cloudy pink amber color with a dissipating tan/pink head that has a true snap to the ear. Dry pale malt, yogurt, cobwebs, not quite ripe raspberries and a touch of iron in the aroma. Inital tip of the tongue detects some sweetness, but it is quickly escorted away. Sourness is there, but it is not so puckering to chase one away. Finish is quite acetic and acidic. After anouther repour, I did detect, as I did slightly in the first pour, a hint of canned salmon in the nose. Seems to stick in the back of the mouth.
UPDATED: MAR 24, 2007 WCC2-Cloudy red mahogany colorwith a nice white head.  Earthy aroma with some fruits.  Very tart, fruity taste.  Very true to the style.

WCCII: Hazy pink red brown with large shost lasting pale pink head. Full skin yeast, cider sour and unripened raspberry aroma. Big full tart n dry palate. Mainly strong citric sour and high yeasty, with light unripened framboise flavours only coming through right at the very dry end.
Murky brown color.  I guess Im still not in the swing of things with Gueuze/Frambroise.  It was very sour or tart, with some fruity under currents.  Tart finish.

2001 Vintage. Pours a blood orange color. Flavor is of very fresh tart raspberries, and a slight wood. Flavor is of tart raspberries, wood then more tartness. Nice but a just a toe over the too sour line.

Cloudy sky at sunset, fluffy light pink head.  Nose of barnyard, honey, lemon rind, and raspberry.  Oh yeah....vodka face with a beer!  Super sour flavors of raspberry, lemon, and slight hints of earth.  Medium bodied, very tart, dry finish.  For the style, you don't get much better...

2001 vintage. Clouded red-orange. Not as red or pink as expected. This is a good thing! Aroma is sour, obviously, with a tart raspberry and strawberry blend. The taste is sour with some stronger acidic notes. Definite fruit taste with some dry, tartness during the finish. Great beer!

Very murky, burnt orange ale with a small, creamy, light pink head. The nose is of lemon juice, lime and, of course, raspberries. The flavor is of underripe raspberries, lemon and Sour Patch Kids... very sour. Medium-bodied with a dry mouthfeel and light carbonation (hmm?). Short, sour, bone-dry finish. Every bit the world class brew!
UPDATED: DEC 27, 2012 2001... Hazy pink red color with a pinkish off white head and some lacing.  Funky aroma of horseblanket and some fruits too.  Tart and acidic, fruit taste, very nice.

2001 vintage. Beer gushes slightly, but the head disappears almost immediately. Pinkish red color. Strong raspberry, lemon and oak aroma. Also a raspberry and lemon flavor, but not as powerfull as in the aroma. Fairly dry with some remaining fruity sweetness. Not too sour, but lively and refreshing. Dry mouthfeel. Tannines. This is a framboise lambic as it should be!

750mL bottle, lambic flute.  Raspberries, cheese and oak are the first aromas that hit the nose.  The overall impression I get reminds me of ocean fishing on a cold night.  Deep, slightly hazy, amber body is crowned by a tall, but quickly diminishing, fizzy pink head.  Pretty standard overwhelming sourness like all Cantillons with more oak presence than usual.  The body seems a bit thinner than some of their other brews.  Also, I really just can't grasp any depth here.  Yeah, it's good, but not complex, imo.  The bottom line is: sort of a let down after the other Lou Pepes.

Pink color. Medium pinkish head. Aroma is tart and fruity. A medium bodied lambic. Very tart and sour, yet the fruit and malt shine. Bright yeasts. Cheesy and funky and woody, yet it’s the tart sourness that dominates this beer. Nice flavor, but not for everyone. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2009 2001: nice funky sourness surrounding berries with some dank cheesiness in there..all coming from a superb red color within the glass..a thin whitish head...subtle raspberries dance about the lovely brett tastes...the tartness isnt too out of control lending itself to a very relaxing atmosphere..somewhat dry with a breeze of berry essence.
pink grapefruit colored pour with a sour aroma and flavor. the taste is sour sour sour. not for the feint at heart.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2016 2001 Bottle Date, 2002 Cork Date: Sampled November 2016
The cork was old enough to start to disintegrate as I pulled it out, luckily most of it made its way out. The beer pours with a tan, one-finger thick, head. The beer is a concentrated amber color and shows a brilliantly clear, red-tinged, amber hue when held up to the light. Bright, ripe, floral, expressive raspberry aromatics greet my nose as I smell this. There is almost a childrens aspirin like quality here, but it is various shades of raspberry that completely dominate the nose.
Dry, effervescent, and quite sour, the beer finishes with a huge raspberry character, and something a bit like childrens aspirin. Tannic raspberry skins create an astringent finish that makes the acidity all that much more sharp. Musty underlying malt and lambic fermentation notes, a certain oak character, a hint of musky / barnyard, and a sharpness that suggests of cat-pee. The body is light, with a nice carbonation, yet has some tannic / lactic body to it that keeps it well away from being thin.
Unlike my notes on the 2002 bottle date, sampled in 2004, you definitely are not going to miss the raspberry character in this beer, it is quite omnipresent, and I wonder if that has to do with this specific vintage, or somehow the age has accentuated the raspberries. This is on the hard side of sour, and it is interesting that hard-sour Lambics seem to be a thing of the past now-a-days; most of the Lambic blenders have gone away from releasing beers that are this sour, though this one could have gotten more sour in the bottle. These Cantillon Raspberry Lambics see to have incredible aging potential; this one is 15 years old, and isnt showing any signs of being too old; this aligns well with the 17 year old Rosé De Gambrinus that I have had in the past too.
Bottle Vintage 2002, Sampled February 2004
Pours a deep hazy red color.  It is well carbonated and produces a pink head as I pour it into my glass, though the head disappears quickly.  There is an immediate aroma of raspberry seeds (fruity and woody).  A slight sour aroma is joined by a musty leather note, though raspberries certainly dominate the nose.  There is a good raspberry presence in the taste as well.  The raspberry fruitiness makes it seem like there is a hint of sweetness in this otherwise austerely dry Cantillon offering.  As expected this is fairly sour, though not extreme.  The beer has a tannic, woody aftertaste that coats the teeth and mouth like a tannic red wine.  A bit musty, but overall the Brettanomyces character seems subdued.

This beer definitely expresses the raspberry character more than the Rose De Gambrinus, though this is still quite dry so that the fruit can be hard to pick up if you dont know what to look for.  I really like how the acidity pairs with the fruit character.  This is a very well integrated beer, no one element overpowers the other.

Cloudy red color,small red head that faded quickly to leae a small faint lace behind.The aroma was barnyard and sour with a decent fruity accent.The taste was sour as hell with a nice raspberry flavor and some earthy tones to it as well.The after taste was berry and the finish was dry as the desert.One hell of a nice brew,and i think i'm starting to get the hang of these brews finally.
Dark red in color...Flavor is of rasperries and sour notes...Very dry and acidic with some hint of sweetness.  very nice
Cloudy brownish red. Smells of, oh I don't know, raspberries, maybe? Tart fruit, clean palate and acidic flavors, as well. Amazingly dry for something this fruity. Very impressive.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2004 2001 - Beautiful pour and aroma - that is where the fun stops! While more tolerable than the Kriek, this is just too tart for me to enjoy.  I couldn't get to the sweetness beyond the bitterness.  Finished on the dry side.  I'm glad others enjoyed it more than I, or I would have felt my $22 didn't go very far at the Southeastern gathering.
2001 vintage. This is much different from any fruit lambics I've had in the past. Orangish red appearance. Aroma is sour fruit. Flavor is sour apple and cherry. EXTREMELY SOUR but very good.
I can describe this in one word...sharp.  The aroma is very cutting in the nose, tart and sour, with raspberry flavoring as an afterthought.  Damp wood and cardboard in the aftertaste.

2001 Vintage.  Pours a rich amber red color with a foamy pinkish head.  Aroma is slightly woodsy with the sharp tartness of raspberries blended with it.  Flavor is slightly sour, but mostly reminiscent of raspberries with some woodsy underflavors.  Gets sweeter as it warms, full of yummy raspberries.

2001 bottle. Head is initially small, fizzy, pink, mostly diminishing. Body is hazy medium red, bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), lightly yeasty (barnyard), with notes of raspberry and cask wood. Flavor is moderately sweet, heavily acidic. Finish is lightly sweet, heavily acidic. Light to medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately astringent. Nice for a fruit lambic, good flavor balance, although raspberry dominates the aroma.  Would expect more yeast character in a traditional lambic, but as with most other Cantillons I've reviewed, the base aroma is fairly mild/meek/light. But the raspberry aroma is delightful and genuine here, so it was enjoyable.

2001.  Shocking pinkish red color, amazing they got this without food coloring.  Pink head fades.  Sour, horse blanket lambic nose, hints of rotting fruit.  Sour in the mouth, horse blanket, funk, then moving smoothly into a greenish raspberry flavor with a touch of sweetness.  Just great stuff.  Super Bowl beer!

2001 vintage.  Red-pink body which is quite clear, especially for a lambic-based product.  There was a pink head when I poured it out, but it disappeared almost instantly.  The aroma combines the sourness from the lambic whit the sweet fruitiness from the rasp-berries.  The flavour is almost what the aroma predicts.  Sourness combined with rasp-berries.  Although, I find the lambic has a dominant role in the flavour in contrast of the Cantillon Rose de Gambrinus.  The initial flavour is moderate sweet - sour, and it finishes stronger sweet and sour.  Quite long-lasting finish.  The beer is accompagnied by a fizzy mouthfeel.
Bottle of the 2001 vintage.  Reddish grapefruit color with a pinkish laced head.  A strong viney rasberry aroma.  Extremely dry.

2003 bottle.  Initially I didn't get much head, but I did when I had the yeast of the last pour from the bottle.  Opaque hazy, beautiful red (matched in quality only by New Glarus Belgian Red).  Good aroma, it leaps from the glass driven by a propellant of some stripe (not the alcohol).  Good fruitiness, though I'm in love with the particular qualities of raspberry in beer.  Still, enjoyable.  The sourness is muted, not jawdropping as in some Cantillon beers.  The yeast acts nicely to give some underlying barnyard qualities.

2001: Slighty hazy reddish hue with large fizzy pink head and good lace. Aroma displays the tart raspberry, barnyard yeast esters, oaken barrel, and aromatic hops I was fully expecting. Sour, mouth puckering, raspberry taste is very much on the front line of this beer. A nice undertone of creamy/sweet malt, fiesty yeast, and bitter hops round out what would have been a one-diminsional beer without them. The mouthfeel is lively yet soft and very dry upon the finish. While this beer style isn't for everyone, those who do enjoy a fruit lambic will surely enjoy this. YUMMY! Rating #900!

My second cantillon offering and this brewery is quickly becoming a favorite. What a fabulous beer, slightly hazy, pink/rasberry with a filmy head. The beer has similar characteristics of the gueze, musty, tart, with the rasberry coming in towards the finish, adding fruit wallop and subtle sweetness that balances and lingers. Great beer.

Sticker on the bottle says 2001, but the cork says 2002.  Pours a pale copper ruby with a 1" thick white head.  Good carbonation throughout.  Aroma of soft tart raspberries.  Flavors include cider vinegar, dry oak, and a light bitterness from the raspberries.  Also a faint sweetness, nowhere near as sweet as Lindemans.  Finishes dry and tart.  I liked this much better than the Lou Pepe Pure Kriek.

Draught Moan and Dove, AMherst MA...Deep red/raspberry colour.  Woody, barnyard, raspberry blossom, sour nose.  Earthy, wood, acidic and delicious.  Sour, pure and blissful.  I love it, as does my lovely raspberry girl, who wants some cheese to mingle with on her palate...

The meandering hard pan path leads me through the woods. . . Oak is in the air, at once I stumble upon a small wading pool that has a deep red tint, the pool is spring fed and the trickle of water is passing through a patch of raspberries, collecting the flesh from many of the large red berries.  I inhaled deeply and am rewarded with a nose full of raspberries, mixed with mud and stone.  I am drawn to the pool by a supernatural force, without thinking, I kneel and plunge my head into the liquid. . . raspberry seeds stick into my teeth, and the flesh ends up all over my face. . . I drink deeply, have my fill and as I look up, see Todd looking me in the face, all I can do is nod and smile in approval. . . I think he understands, Thank you.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2011 2004 Vintage, rated 2011. Murky reddish-brown colour. Thin head.  Sweet raspberry aroma with cork, and light wood...kind of yoghurty.  Very tart, grippy sourness.  Lots of raspberry, wood, maybe light vanilla and faint brettanomyces funk.  Clean, and while not really balanced, it has the sense of balance that a lambic lover appreciates.  Same score. 2003 rating:  Deep hazy raspberry colour.  Rich wood, yoghurt notes. The raspberry comes off very fres.  Deep tartness beautifully balances the fruit.  Best framboise Ive ever had.  Thanks, Todd.

My impression is of sour, rotting, rasberries.  This sounds like a negative, but it's not in the hands of this brewery!  It's quite good, though I was left wondering how it's different from a cherry lambic...
(2000 @RBSG2003):  Pink/red cloudy body.  Aroma is barnyard and raspberry.  Taste is tart! then raspberry once you get past that (though that's not easy).  Light body.

2000 version.  Massive raspberry nose actually tickled my nose. Very minute mustiness and woody aromas.  Tart to the tongue and a bit salty, this is raspberry overload, not leaving much for the natural lambic taste.  Still, a fine example of beer 'brewing'  artistry that is so rare and specific that I wonder if items like this will continue to be produced in the future!Earlier Rating: 10/21/2002 Total Score: 4.11999 LOU PEPE VERSION.  Champaign like feel with bursts of real fresh strawberrys.  Twice as many strawberrys in this than any other. Dry, barely sour end that tapered down the berry burst.  This can be used as a salad dressing for excellent results, but it runs about $50 per bottle.  Not a session beer by far, but a very interesting beer to sample.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2003 A nice beautiful pink/red body and a light pink head.  The aroma is rather tart and acidic.  Not as intensely sour as other Cantillon lambics.  The flavor was plagued by the same relative mildness.  Still an amazing beer, but not quite the gem that other Cantillon's have been.
RBSG2003. Far more tart than other quality Framboise I've had, less smooth somehow, less horseblanket/diaper aromas. A bit thin also.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2003 '00 version sampled draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, Sweden in April 2003. 
Clear red and hazy. Acidic nose with fresh raspberries. The normal Cantillon sourness is here balanced by a welth of sweet, fresh raspberries. Complex and lightly woody with citric acid finish.

Note: '99 means released now.
Colour: unbelievable deep cherry-red. When yeast mixes in, slight brown haze. Very little head (fruitacids and kernelcontents), deep rosy-red, but fast disappearing.
Nose: as a bucket of freshly plucked raspberries - only intenser. Slight nose of wet wood at the back. Also a waft of wet chalk on a blackboard. Taste: taste as from wild raspberries, but more subdued, with heavier wooden overtones. First impression, surprisingly, as from a southern Europe landwine, slightly diluted with water. Extremely refreshing. Very deep retronasal flavour, not aggressive, sourness mainly fruit acids. Hints of lactic acid and acetic acid, but below identification threshold.
Aftertaste: raspberries, lingering on and on, tart.
Mouthfeel: rather sharp, very dry but not aggressively so.

Lou Pepe ('Gramps' in Langue d'Oc, Occitane) stands for gueuze, kriek or framboise made exclusively with 2 year old lambics, preferably on pipes, used before only for wine (Bordeaux). Added is a sugary liqueur, instead of young lambic for secondary fermentation. Also, the content of fruit per barrel is 50% higher than the 'ordinary' Framboise. This is truly a world classic.
1999 LOU PEPE:  Like the Kriek this is a ruby red color with an understated tart flavor.  The strawberries come bursting out, with not as much sourness.
